speaker: Network. This Is Not A Net Benefit To The New The Speaker
theText: Order! It being 8 pm,Wednesday, 12 October 2005 ----Mental Health Week and to touch on a few issues related to that. It is important to reflect on the overall costs of mental health to the community. We know from an Australian National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing that 20 per cent of adult Australians experience a mental health problem, 14 per cent of children and adolescents experience mental illness and three per cent of adults have a serious mental illness. If you look at mental illness in terms of the total disease burden in this country, you will see that it is roughly 13 per cent. It represents roughly 30 per cent of the non-fatal disease burden. Clearly, it is a very significant problem. If you look at the suicide rate for last year, you will see that it was 2,454 people. A significant majority of those people committed suicide as a consequence of their mental illness. One would think, given the scope of this particular problem in the community, that governments of all persuasions would be putting bucket loads of funding into solving this issue. Unfortunately, as I continue to report to this House, funding across all levels of government for mental health is about seven per cent of the total health budget. We have a massive problem: some 2,454 Australians committing suicide per year, mostly as a consequence of this particular problem, yet seven per cent of the total government health budget across this country is spent on mental health. I think that is a disgrace, particularly when you look at countries like New Zealand that spend roughly 14 per cent of their health budget on mental health. I would like to think that we would lead New Zealand in a whole range of areas-we trumpet that. So we are behind other First World countries. Many other First World countries spend between 10 and 14 per cent of their total health budget on mental health. The fact is that 62 per cent of Australians who have a mental health problem cannot access mental health services. Of the 38 per cent who do, most will see a GP. They are the gatekeepers for our mental health system. Unfortunately I report to this House today that, if you look at the Better Outcomes in Mental Health program that helps doctors treat people with mental illness, you will see that it had an underspend of $63 million. This was a $121 million program over four years to help GPs provide better mental health outcomes to patients-the some 38 per cent of people who access those services. The fact is that, in commemorating Mental Health Week and looking at the mental health of Australians, when we look at government inaction and underspending on this issue, for the least advantaged in our community, it is a national disgrace. We have to do something about it or more Australians will die. (Time expired) Lucas Heights Reactor visit ANSTO’s Lucas Heights research station and be given a tour of that facility. In particular, I was fortunate to see the new OPAL reactor that is currently being constructed there. The visit was certainly an eye-catching and eye-opening moment. I saw the processes conducted at the reactor that contribute to many of the health treatments of diseases that we have in Australia, including cardiac disease, cancer and the like. I strongly believe that science and technolMAIN COMMITTEE

title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Tollner (Solomon) (10.13 Am)
theText: On Friday, 7 OctoberI was fortunate enough toogy into the future will provide us with more options for and solutions to the treatment of serious, and possibly terminal, health problems, as is the case with current science and technology. The current reactor generates many of the treatments for cancer patients in Australia at a lower cost than if we were to import products from overseas. After my visit, I am more than ever convinced that the new Lucas Heights reactor plays a critical role in the treatment of many of the health problems of Australians and is critical in solving future health problems. In order for the new reactor to be licensed, the government faces a fairly serious time line to find a possible site for a nuclear waste repository. The government needs to act to ensure that Australians in need of pharmaceuticals do not lose that access. A critical part of the licensing condition for the new OPAL reactor-the open pool Australian light water medical and research reactor-at Lucas Heights is that Australia must have in place a store for our own reprocessed fuel due to the mandatory return of waste from Scotland and France. If a decision on a site for waste management cannot be made within a matter of months, Australia will no longer be allowed to produce radioactive isotopes that are used in hospitals in every state and territory of Australia. For that reason I am very keen to see a decision made very quickly on the location of a suitable repository. My visit to ANSTO was extraordinarily interesting and extraordinarily well conducted. I would particularly like to thank the director of ANSTO, Dr Ian Smith, and all his staff for the wonderful efforts they made to show me around the place. (Time expired) Iraq number of people concerned about the prospects for any kind of peaceful future for Iraq in the near term and to repeat a number of questions that have been put to the government in relation to this issue both by the opposition here in the parliament and by the public and my constituents. It is critical that we not be distracted by cheap politicking from the essential features of the Iraq engagement nor from the fact that this war, which the Howard government took us into, was against the wishes of a majority of Australians. That this military engagement was based on a lie remains a great shame; that it breached the norms and accepted principles of international law is to our discredit. The decision of the Howard government to participate in that most serious of national undertakings without thinking through the consequences that flow from committing troops to the far side of the world without a strategy for engagement or exit is increasingly exposed as short-termism of the worse kind. It is to the great credit of Australia’s service men and women that the engagement has been conducted with great courage and skill, but it is a matter of phenomenal luck that, throughout the war in Iraq, our personnel have been relatively unscathed-and we must fervently hope this remains the case. Tragically, it has not been so in relation to US personnel nor the region generally. These men and women are poorly served by the downpour of cliches that pass for debate from government members on this issue. It seems that members opposite are completely unaware of the international dynamic that led to the war and the increasingly intractable problems that the war has spawned. Central to the Iraq question-especially in light of the growing need for additional resources to be applied to antiterrorism measures and the predicted shortfall of $1 billion per year in the defence budget identified this week by the Kokoda Foundation-is the question of why the government does not simply throw away the neocon MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Garrett (Kingsford Smith) (10.16 Am)
theText: I rise to add my voice to the growingphrasebook and square up to explaining what is happening now in relation to Australia’s ongoing involvement in Iraq. The British Joint Intelligence Committee made it plain in its assessment of February 2003 that the threat from al-Qaeda and associated groups would be heightened by military action against Iraq. This was confirmed by AFP Commissioner Mick Keelty before the government pulled him into line. The French Ambassador remarked only this morning that France’s stance on the war was right and Australia’s wrong. Notwithstanding the upcoming referendum on an Iraq constitution, it is difficult to conceive of anything other than increasing instability, terrorism and violence in Iraq. That is to be hugely regretted. So it is time for the government to explain clearly what it now means by ‘getting the job done’. Are there conditions and a timetable for troop withdrawal? What will our response be if civil war breaks out across Iraq? What in the interim will be done in relation to the pressing, serious shortfalls in security capacity in our region? Those are the questions for the Prime Minister and the foreign minister, and we demand an answer. (Time expired) St Vincent de Paul Society equipment grants through which the residents of La Trobe were able to secure $25,000 in funding. One of the recipients was the St Vincent de Paul Society in Upper Ferntree Gully, which received over $2,000 through the round of volunteer small equipment grants. St Vincent de Paul received the grant for an electric heater and 400 reusable food parcel carry bags. It is important to note that any funding these organisations receive must go back to the people they are there to help. Therefore they cannot purchase products like this for their own organisation. I am very glad to say that the Howard government was able to assist them with their needs. I met with Gordon Veerasawmy, Judy Atu, Allan Bailey, Dennis Buckley, Bev McNamara, Connie Bala, Elsie Johnson, Wally Johnson, Brother Michael, Peter Springfellow, Vivian Springfellow and Adele Paterson on 27 August this year to discuss local issues and congratulate them on the valuable contribution they make to the local community. The society exists primarily to provide home assistance to the poor. It understands their personal need for as much assistance as its resources will allow. I am thrilled that the society was successful in its application under this grants scheme as it acknowledges the hard work and dedication of these local volunteers. Each of the society’s members works tirelessly on a voluntary basis, providing one-on-one assistance for the people of our local community who need the most help. Each month they assist approximately 30 people through their efforts. The provision of an electric heater and reusable food parcels carry bags will make a significant difference to the services they provide to the local community. This organisation may not have been otherwise able to afford these items. On a final note, I would like to make special mention of Gordon Veerasawmy, who went above and beyond the group’s responsibilities recently after I received a call for help from Merv and Elaine Vincent, who had an old stove they needed removed but were unable to do it themselves. My office contacted Gordon to see if there was anything the society could do. Gordon, with the assistance of Dennis, quickly went to the house, removed the heater and took it to the tip. It is little things like this which make St Vincent de Paul’s a great community MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Wood (La Trobe) (10.19 Am)
theText: I rise to tell the House about the great volunteer smallgroup. Again, I wish to strongly thank this organisation for the fantastic work they do in the local community. Telecommunications Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide) (10.22 am)-There is significant concern within our community about the installation of mobile phone towers in heavily populated areas. This concern is especially serious when towers are installed near sensitive areas such as schools, kindergartens and hospitals. TodayI rise to reaffirm Labor’s commitment to strengthening the regulatory policies governing mobile phone towers and highlight the shambles created by a government unable to show leadership over a dispute between local councils, communities and the growing telecommunications industry. Battlelines have been drawn in the Australian suburbs, with communities fearing the effects of mobile communication towers on their health and councils and telecommunications at each other in the courts seeking clarification over legislation. This crisis was highlighted again to me the other day when I met with some residents of Goodwood who were concerned over potential health risks associated with a mobile phone tower that has been built, without community input, on a building next to a local primary school. Although it had been modified after pressure from the community and local councils, people were still concerned about health risks and the inability of local councils to significantly alter the construction of these towers. Unley City Council Mayor, Mr Michael Keenan-a very good and hard working mayor, I might add-is so concerned about telecommunications companies simply bypassing council planning regulations that he tabled a report at the Unley City Council meeting that led to a motion financially supporting a legal battle that has now reached the High Court. He believes the council has no option but to add their support, for, if successful, telecommunications companies will have a legal precedent to bypass local council processes in the future. Telecommunications companies are arguing in the courts that they are exempt from council planning processes due to the Telecommunications Act. Local councils consider the towers constitute a development issue and are therefore under their jurisdiction. In the latest round, the Supreme Court ruled in favour of the councils, though granted leave for the telecommunications company to appeal the decision in the High Court. This is a problem that could have been easily solved by simple legislation and some government leadership, instead of lengthy court battles. Labor released a policy at the last election that would have directly confronted this issue, promising to introduce stricter guidelines, give support for local council procedures and continue to listen to and act on the concerns of local communities. I want to reaffirm this commitment and call on the government to implement Labor’s initiative and provide some leadership on the issue. I pledge to my constituents in Goodwood-and, indeed, to all of the constituents in Adelaide-that I shall continue to fight for the rights of local communities when it comes to the placement of mobile phone towers in our neighbourhoods. I would also like to pledge my support to Mayor Michael Keenan and the Unley council for the action that they are taking to stick up for the residents of Adelaide. Kingston Electorate: Gambling Facilities sue which is facing my electorate: the location of a new gaming facility with up to 40 new MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Richardson (Kingston) (10.25 Am)
theText: I rise today to talk about a very important ispoker machines in the suburb of Morphett Vale. This is a suburb which is already highly saturated with clubs and pubs. Straight opposite the proposed site is an RSL eternal flame site along with the Morphett Vale Memorial Bowling Club and the Morphett Vale Football Club. According to local welfare groups which are dealing with the issue of problem gambling at a grassroots level, this particular suburb already has a higher than average rate of gambling addiction, associated social problems and family breakdown. This is an area which has been targeted by Club One. The proprietors have lodged the development application with the City of Onkaparinga because its high level of problem gamblers will ensure higher profits. These unscrupulous operators are targeting the area with no thought for the social consequences and without concern for the lives, families and communities they will destroy. There are houses within 80 metres of this proposed pokie parlour whose occupants enjoy a pleasant and peaceful lifestyle. If this new gaming facility is to be approved, their lives and the value of their homes are about to deteriorate. The late-night trading hours applied for-up to midnight during the week, 2 am on Saturdays and midnight on Sunday nights-are absolutely disgraceful. There is limited parking available on this site already, and with the additional customers to the site people will be parking in the side streets and in front of these homes. The extra noise and vehicles at midnight or at 2 am are certainly not what the residents in that area are looking forward to. I initially doorknocked and within two hours I had obtained 500 signatures to a petition which has now been lodged with the City of Onkaparinga council. Since then I have collected a further 2,000 signatures to the petition to ensure that this proposed pokie facility does not go ahead. I would like to thank the residents and concerned citizens of the southern suburbs for their commitment to saying enough is enough. As a former police officer within the southern suburbs, I have seen first-hand the problem effects of gambling and what it does to a poor socioeconomic area such as the southern suburbs. We are fighting for this one to ensure that it does not go ahead for the people of the southern suburbs and for the people of Adelaide. Nuclear Waste Storage to the last federal election and prior to the last Northern Territory election, Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, announced three possible sites for nuclear waste repositories in the Northern Territory. As I said earlier, this was despite undertakings given and promises made prior to the last federal election. Since the announcement in July, Territorians of all political flavours have rallied in their opposition to the proposal. They have rallied in seeking information and clarification from the Commonwealth about what is proposed. They want answers to fundamental questions such as: is the Territory the safest place to store nuclear waste and is it scientifically demonstrated to be the best option? What they learnt subsequently is that it is not. The most preferred sites are in New South Wales, in National Party and Liberal Party seats. Has the decision to place nuclear waste in the Territory been a political convenience? Of course it has, as evidenced by the fact that the most preferred sites are in fact in New South Wales. They want answers to these questions and to the observation made by Brendan Nelson: … why on earth can’t people in the middle of nowhere have low level and intermediate level waste? You can imagine the anger of the people of the Northern Territory when they heard that, particularly the traditional owners of the country which has been identified as a possible site. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Snowdon (Lingiari) (10.28 Am)
theText: On 15 July this year, despite promises made priorThere are three sites: one to the north-west of Alice Springs, one to the north-east of Alice Springs and one to the south-west of Katherine. People are angry at the failure of the government to take them into its confidence, consult with them and talk to them about what it was proposing. The Central Australia Community Alliance has been formed to oppose a proposal for nuclear waste facilities. This alliance is made up of members of political parties, environment groups, Indigenous organisations and traditional owners, as well as local government. One of its first actions was to organise a public meeting to hear the views of the community before a panel of representatives of local government, Territory government and environment groups. I was also on the panel as the federal member. The meeting prepared a list of questions which was forwarded to Brendan Nelson. Of course, we have had no response. Three hundred people attended this meeting. I am pleased to say that, since this initial public meeting, the community has conducted a very successful Hiroshima Day rally, based on their opposition to the expansion of the nuclear industry but most particularly the proposition of nuclear waste dumps in the Northern Territory. Finally, last week Lhere Artepe, the Aboriginal corporation representing traditional owners, held a march and meeting in Alice Springs. This rally was supported by the Arid Land Environmental Centre, the Australian Conservation FoundationA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 10.31 am to 10.35 am statements, I want to apologise to the member for Lingiari. IfI had been more on guard, I would have let him finish the 17 seconds remaining for his statement. Council and the Alice Springs Town Council gave the Indigenous perspective on the opposition to the dump. The campaign continues and Territorians are united in their resolve to prevent the government imposing nuclear waste facilities on the Northern Territory without the agreement of the Northern Territory government or the community. Cowper Electorate: Telecommunications this House is an important milestone for telecommunications in this country. The $3.1 billion Connecting Australia program-providing $1.1 billion for mobile phone and broadband and $2 billion for the Future Fund to ensure that regional Australia gets excellent telecommunications services not only now but into the future-is vital to the future of this nation. The government realises that, if we are to have competitive small businesses, quality educational services, good health services and economic development in regional and rural areas, we need to have telecommunications infrastructure that is going to support that. Telecommunications is playing very much the role that the railways did in the 19th century in providing opportunities for business in more isolated areas. I would like to comment on some new facilities that have been installed in my electorate. The mobile phone tower near the small town of Bowraville in the Nambucca Valley will mean not only improved telecommunications services for the locals but also greater convenience and safety for people who are perhaps working out on farms by themselves, and tourists will be able to travel throughout the Nambucca Valley and still be in contact with their offices. speaker: Mr Hartsuyker (Cowper) (10.36 Am)
theText: The passing of the Telstra legislation throughMany tourists cannot be away from phone services; they need to be able to stay in contact with their office in order to have a holiday. Another tower has been installed in the town of Maclean. When it is fully commissioned, it will provide improved CDMA and GSM services for the town of Maclean, the area of the Pacific Highway near the town and areas in the west of Yamba which have suffered from poorer mobile phone services than would be ideal. SoI am delighted to see these two towers, in particular, being installed in my electorate in response to the telecommunications needs of the people in the electorate of Cowper. A tower was also recently installed in upper Macleay, near the town of Bellbrook. Despite there being a relatively low population density in that area, this tower is providing much needed mobile phone communications in a sparsely populated area. This was supported by the government. This tower would not have been there except for the telecommunications policies of this government to ensure that people in regional and rural areas have equity of access to telecommunications services. These services are vital if we are going to expand our business opportunities in those areas. They are vital to the safety of the people of the upper Macleay Valley and are vital in providing equity of opportunity for people who want to live right around this country. The government recognises the fact that there is a role for government in providing services which would not be provided on a commercial basis. The government believes that it should be spending taxpayers’ money not on subsidising phone companies but on providing telecommunications services which would not be viable on a commercial basis. in 60 seconds, but I propose to allow the member for Port Adelaide to have the whole three minutes-and I thank the member for Gellibrand for reducing her speech to accommodate that. Public Transport for Gellibrand as well. On 21 September I was asked by the business groups of the western suburbs of Adelaide to give an address to their meeting-a non-political speech on humour, public transport and the history of transport in Port Adelaide and the western suburbs. It was a fascinating exercise to delve into the history of public transport in South Australia and make some comparisons in the modern context with what goes on today. It was interesting to find out that South Australia built the first railway from Adelaide to Port Adelaide but the railway sleepers were set longitudinally, not at right angles. Of course, on the first trip with all the dignitaries on board, the obvious thing happened. The rail also had no ballast and so the locomotive ploughed a 30-metre furrow through the ground. It was a very embarrassing start. It is interesting also to note that in 1860 the frequency of the services from Port Adelaide to Adelaide was 20 minutes. That is better than it is today. In the 1950s the transport system from Port Adelaide to Adelaide ran every two minutes in peak period. That is far better than it is today. There are some principles about public transport in Australia that only one city, today, has ever followed. I will come to that in a moment. Trains are most useful for long distances, speed, and they need to run at a frequency of at least 15 minutes. Trams are most useful and MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members
