theText: The time for members’ statements will expire
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Sawford (Port Adelaide) (10.39 Am)
theText: I appreciate the contribution by the membermuch better than buses or any other form of transport on regular routes and buses are used for the rest. It is interesting in a modern context that only one city in this country fulfils the trifecta of good public transport principles and that is Melbourne. Perth and Brisbane have excellent modern electric rail systems but little else. They have one-way streets and an overreliance on buses and a very poor public transport system. Adelaide is showing some signs of moving in the right direction by extending its only light rail system and hopefully joining it in-as the people in Melbourne did with Port Melbourne and St Kilda-to the rail network. It is interesting that the biggest and the smallest cities in Australia, Sydney and Hobart, have absolutely the worse public transport. They do not follow any principles whatsoever. In Sydney, their rail system is in trouble. They have no tram system to speak of, there is an overreliance on buses and they rely on one-way streets. Hobart, the smallest city in Australia, does exactly the same. Why, God only knows. It is hard to admit sometimes as a South Australian that the Victorians have actually got it right in public transport. Whenever you hear criticism of Victorian public transport I hope that it is made in the context that they are correct. agreed to in the House earlier, the time for members’ statements has concluded. Second Reading Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock: That this bill be now read a second time. Ms ROXON (Gellibrand) (10.42 am)-The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 does have a long history, which I will take some time later in my speech to go through. The bill before the House now introduces a number of amendments which will tidy up the act, extend provisions for the use of intercepted material and provide that certain agencies are now eligible to access the powers granted under the act. The bill adds an additional paragraph into the act allowing that the prohibition against interception would not apply in relation to the interception of a stored communication. I will go into the definition of ‘stored communication’ in some detail. Essentially, the bill before us today seeks to implement five measures. Firstly, it will extend the use of intercepted material for the following currently eligible authorities: the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption; the New South Wales Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission; and the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission. The bill will correct anomalies concerning these bodies which will enable them to have effective use of intercepted material. This will allow those bodies to use lawfully obtained intercepted material to the full extent envisaged by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Additionally, it will allow the Inspector of ICAC, the Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission and the Crime and Misconduct Commission to similarly receive and use lawfully obtained intercepted material to the extent that other eligible authorities are permitted to under the interception act. Secondly, it will expand the list of eligible state authorities by two, adding the Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption to the list. Under the amendments, these state authorities will now be able MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: The Deputy Speaker ( Mr Lindsay)
theText: Order! In accordance with the resolutionto access the act’s powers, allowing them to receive and use lawfully obtained intercepted material for the purpose of the investigation of police corruption and misconduct. This is partially the outcome of a settlement between the Commonwealth and Victoria and it is contingent on the enactment of certain legislation by Victoria, which I will discuss later. The legislation will not operate if suitable arrangements and legislation are not in place in Victoria within the relevant time frame. Thirdly, this bill will extend provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant for an additional six months. Essentially, this will allow the status quo to continue for the following six months. A ‘stored communication’ is defined in the bill as a communication that is stored on equipment or any other thing, but does not include communication stored on a highly transitory basis such as voice over IP or any other communication where the storage is merely transitory as an integral part of the technology used in its transmission. This exception will have effect for 18 months. There was an original 12 months proposed in an earlier bill and an additional six months extension to the sunset clause. Within this time a review of the act is to be undertaken. The time frame of 18 months for the review is appropriate given the far-reaching recommendations of the Blunn review, the complex nature of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and the even more complex nature of modern telecommunications technology. There are a number of recommendations made by the review of access to stored communications. The government has requested an additional six months to consider changes to the interception act and we believe that this is appropriate given the complexity of the issues at hand. We accept that the extension of the sunset clause is necessary to allow the government additional time within which to properly assess and respond to the substantive findings and recommendations of the Blunn review. This review was constituted in March this year and completed in August. Fourthly, the bill will clarify the expression ‘officer of state’ to include all members of police services of that state. Under the previous legislation there was uncertainty as to whether police officers were covered. The amendments clarify this and it now means that it will be a permitted purpose under the act for the state police to pass lawfully intercepted material to a body established to investigate alleged misbehaviour of a member of the police force. Finally, this bill will remove references to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 consequential to the enactment of the Legislative Instruments Act 2003. The amendment in this section will clarify that, when the minister makes a declaration under section 34 of the interception act, the minister is creating a legislative instrument. The effect of this will be that such declarations will fall under the definition of a legislative instrument that is present in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. As I mentioned earlier, the bill will add the Victorian Office of Police Integrity to the list of organisations with access to the powers under the act. The Victorian Office of Police Integrity, upon its establishment in November 2004, was initially refused a grant of these powers under the act by the federal government. The reason given for the refusal for the grant of powers was an apparent conflict of interest by the Victorian Ombudsman who was responsible for both running the new body and also, in his role as Ombudsman, the oversight of such powers. The Victorian government has agreed to introduce appropriate oversight amendments and, in accordance with this, the current bill grants interception powers to the OPI for 12 months MAIN COMMITTEE from the assent of this bill. Within that time frame the Victorian government has agreed to enact the oversight legislation or face the loss of those powers if it does not do so. This represents a significant win for the Bracks government of Victoria and a significant cave in by the Howard government. The extension of the telecommunications interception powers was first called for by Premier Bracks some time ago and the Bracks government has to be congratulated for being able to now resolve this issue. I would also like to congratulate the Howard government for backing down from its original position and agreeing to the request made by the Victorian government. Despite initially resisting the call from the Bracks government for alterations to the act, it has subsequently decided to act on the recommendations of the Victorian state government. It is refreshing to see that the government, in this instance at least, has not allowed its extremist ideological predispositions to interfere with its common sense. The bill will assist state agencies in their fight against corruption and as such should be supported. The Labor Party is supporting the bill with the extension of the sunset clause by six months. The Labor Party, as I have mentioned, has supported the extension due to the extensive nature of the Blunn review. The review identified the need for a comprehensive and overriding legislative framework to deal with access to telecommunications for the purpose of security and law enforcement. While speaking on this bill, I must note that this is the third bill that the government has introduced to sort out the issue of stored communications under the act. An initial bill providing for amendments to the act was introduced in 2002. Its intent was to remove the requirement for a telecommunications interception warrant where a stored communication could have been accessed without the use of a telecommunications line. A colleague in the Senate, a member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, has advised me that the committee recommended the opposite to this proposal in 2002 and recommended that such data did require a TI warrant in order to be accessed. As a result of the good work of that committee, the provisions of that bill were withdrawn by the government. Then a second bill was introduced which largely kept intact the powers to access a TI stored communication without a warrant but introduced new provisions to distinguish between messages which had been accessed by the recipient and those that had not. Under the regime of the second bill, a message could be accessed without a warrant if it could be accessed without the use of a telecommunications line and it had already been accessed by the recipient. This second bill had further provisions for accessing a message where it had not already been accessed by the recipient but where access could be gained with equipment that the intended recipient could have used and this did not require the use of a telecommunications line. However, practical difficulties became evident with the second bill. Evidence was heard by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee that it would be difficult for an internet service provider to ascertain what had been accessed by the recipient and what had not. Furthermore, there was significant confusion: differing accounts from the Attorney-General’s Department and the Australian Federal Police as to whether powers already granted to the Federal Police allowed access to stored information without a warrant. The Senate committee further recommended, firstly, that the legislation be deferred until there was agreement between the AFP and the A-G’s department on the operation of the TI regime and, secondly, that MAIN COMMITTEE the bill be amended to provide for a review of its operation and consideration of whether stored communications should be exempt from the review. The provisions in the second bill which covered the stored communications exception to the interception power were to have a period of effect for 12 months from the date of the commencement. The Attorney-General also proposed that within that time a review of the act would be conducted. At that time the committee accepted the undertaking with the caveat that any review would be public, that it would seek submissions from the public and that its findings would be made public. The Blunn review accomplished both of these goals in seeking public submissions, which are now publicly available. The government did not ultimately proceed with this second bill. Instead it has introduced this third bill, which is before us today. Labor is prepared to support this bill, although its history is a little tortuous, for the reasons that I have outlined. I commend it to the House. Before resuming my seat, I would like to record my thanks to my colleague Senator Ludwig and, for its work, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which seems to have handled this issue in great detail on many occasions and has done good work for the government in doing so. communications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005. Most honourable members would be aware that the purpose of law enforcement agencies has always remained purely and simply to investigate and arrest those who break the law. A civilised society requires sanctions for those who breach the rules of that society; therefore, it is important that law enforcement agencies are given the appropriate tools to enable them to carry out their duties in the community interest. SoI suppose you could say effectively the law enforcement agencies are the goodies and in some respects they are trying to catch the baddies. But over the years the changes that have occurred to technology have made new tools available to criminals and it is therefore important that crime fighters are able to stay up with the game. Often there is debate in the community as to where the balance should be between individual rights and the need to give law enforcement agencies the tools they require to do their job in an appropriate way. Thus, this is becoming a more and more complex area of legislation and the incredible intricacies of new technologies are well beyond the comprehension of many, and it is very interesting to see the way in which the technological knowledge of our community is galloping ahead at an ever-increasing pace. The purpose of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 is to ensure that some simple legal weapons are available to the various state organisations charged with investigating corruption and protecting the integrity of public positions. Among the modern documents that are now often integral to the investigation of corruption and are required during court proceedings are stored communications. This issue of equipping our crime fighters is a very important one, so earlier this year the Attorney-General, Mr Philip Ruddock-who in my view is one of the very best ministers this government has-appointed Mr AS Blunn AO to investigate the legislative framework that regulates access to stored communications. That report has been completed and its recommendations are being digested by the department. They will also obviously be considered by the government. I think most honourable members would agree that this should be carried out thoroughly. It is important not to make or change policy on the run and in that regard one of the primary MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (10.53 Am)
theText: I am pleased to be able to join the debate on the Telepurposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 is to extend for six months the provision set out in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 that enabled the authorities to access stored communications without first obtaining a warrant as required by the interception act. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested to hear that this was a measure that was first introduced courtesy of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2004-that is last year-along with a sunset clause that would see this valuable crime-fighting provision lapse in mid-December this year. I have to say that I am one of those people who often have a concern that after more than 100 years of Federation we have accumulated on our statute books many laws that are really no longer required. It takes omnibus bills from time to time to clean up some of those irrelevant statutes and remove them from the statute books. An increased use of sunset clauses might mean that our legislation would automatically tidy itself up and not require amendment by omnibus bills, which so often will amend large numbers of acts of this parliament in one hit. Today’s bill simply extends the provision, which would have lapsed in mid-December this year, for an extra six months to mid-June 2006 while the analysis of Mr Blunn’s recommendations on access to stored communications is finalised. I am pleased to hear the shadow Attorney-General, the member for Gellibrand, indicate that the opposition is in fact supporting this bill. The bill will enable better use of intercepted communications by those organisations involved in the investigation of corruption. These include-and I think most members are probably aware of them-the Crime and Misconduct Commission in Queensland, the Office of Police Integrity in Victoria, the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. These bodies already had some provisions available to them under the interception act of 1979, but they were restricted in the way that they could use intercepted documents. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 corrects that problem. Thankfully, unacceptable incidents of public servants behaving corruptly are rare. Any such behaviour by officials, police and any number of other government workers only serves to destabilise our communities, undermine our democracy and bring about a sense of alienation from and disillusionment with the political process. Corruption, once it begins, can quite often lead to further, even bigger crime: commercial fraud, money laundering and organised crime. Not surprisingly, the bill currently before the House will also usher in several other minor changes. It will clarify the definition of an ‘officer of the state’ in that it will come to mean any officers of any of the state police forces-I think they call themselves police services these days-as well as civilian employees of those police services. These employees already came under the guidelines of the act and the bill serves to clear up any uncertainties. This feature also serves to remind all employees involved in the investigation of crimes, and the bringing to justice of those who commit crime, that they are also not above the law. While Australia might be seen to be relatively free of corruption in official positions compared to other countries we hear some quite appalling stories about, there have been documented cases in the past of which Australia ought not be proud. MAIN COMMITTEE This bill gives law enforcement agencies further clout to be able to fulfil their vital functions of weeding out the bad eggs and successfully bringing them to justice. I commend the Attorney on this legislation and commend, in particular, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 to the Main Committee. munications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005. I am also pleased to note that the opposition supports this bill. The purpose of the bill is to extend for six months provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. This bill also adds the Victorian Office of Police Integrity to the list of eligible authorities able to obtain telecommunications interception warrants for law enforcement purposes and allows various state bodies that are already eligible authorities to make greater use of lawfully obtained intercepted material. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Act 2004 introduced into the interception act the concept of a ‘stored communication’ and provided that a stored communication could be intercepted without the need for a telecommunications interception warrant. Access to such communications could therefore be obtained by other lawful means, such as a normal search warrant. The amendments also included a provision to the effect that any information obtained from intercepting a stored communication was not lawfully obtained information for the purposes of the interception act-that is, the information was not subject to the restrictions on use imposed by the interception act. The amendments were intended as an interim measure pending a thorough consideration of how best to regulate access to communications in the everchanging world of technology. As an interim measure the amendments included a 12-month sunset clause, meaning that the provisions will cease to operate on 14 December 2005. Since 1994 there have been four major reviews dealing with telecommunications interception. These were the 1994 review by MrP Barrett into the long-term cost-effectiveness of telecommunications interception; in 1999, a review by MrD Boucher of interception arrangements under section 332R of the Telecommunications Act 1997; the 1999 review by MrP Ford of telecommunications interception policy; and the 2003 review, by MrT Sherman AO, of named person warrants and other matters. The latest review-the Anthony Blunn review of 2005 into the regulation of, and access to, communications-invited submissions from the public and, in particular, from parties which had demonstrated an interest in the previous reviews and in the legislative processes related to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Mr Blunn was asked to review the policy options for the regulation of access to telecommunications, with particular emphasis on new and emerging telecommunications technologies, having particular regard to protecting the privacy of users of the system. Mr Blunn was also asked to consider and comment on the ongoing appropriateness of the current telecommunications interception regime and, if relevant, alternatives for the lawful access to content; the protection of information systems from attack by means of a telecommunications system, including the use of intrusion detection systems and other measures; the cost implications, including cost recovery mechanisms; and any other issues as they arose from the review. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Mrs Vale (Hughes) (11.01 Am)
theText: I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the TelecomMr Blunn has now completed the review of the regulation of access to communications and has made a number of recommendations in relation to stored communications. These recommendations need to be fully considered and, where appropriate, implemented in order to ensure that the interception act is able to meet the demands of new and emerging technologies. This bill will therefore extend for six months the operation of the provisions dealing with access to stored communications. By way of background, the current access regime is regulated through the provisions of the Telecommunications Act and the interception act. Very broadly, the Telecommunications Act, insofar as it is relevant, regulates the networks that carry or are capable of carrying communications. The scheme of the act is built around a structure of licensed carriers and carriage service providers which constitute the network. It concentrates on the obligations of those carriers and carriage service providers and associated persons in relation to accessing that network. Access is dealt with in parts 13, 14 and 15, which respectively deal with the protection of communications, the national interest matters and cooperation with agencies. Importantly, part 13 provides, among other things, that eligible persons must not disclose or use any information accessed in the course of employment that relates to the content or substance of any communication that has been or is being carried by a carrier and carriage service provider, the service supplied or the affairs or personal particulars of another person. There are, however, a number of exceptions, including in relation to content or substance where disclosure or use is required in connection with the operation of an enforcement agency under a warrant or in any other case as required or authorised by law. More broadly, disclosure of information or a document but not in relation to content or substance is expected where disclosure is certified by an authorised officer as reasonably necessary for the purposes of national security, enforcing the criminal law or a law imposing a pecuniary penalty or protecting the public revenue. Part 14 of the Telecommunications Act builds on part 13 in requiring carriers and carriage service providers to do their best to prevent telecommunication networks and facilities being used to commit offences and to give authorities such help as is reasonably necessary for the purposes of (1) enforcing the criminal law and the law imposing penalties, (2) protecting public revenue and (3) safeguarding national security. Part 15 provides the structures through which the obligations in relation to interception are imposed on carrier and carriage service providers. For those purposes, interception consists of listening to or recording communication in its passage over a controlled network or controlled facility. The interception act deals only with the interception of telecommunications passing over a telecommunications system. Other than as provided, the act makes it an offence to intercept such communications. For the purposes of the act, interception consists of listening to or recording by any means a communication passing over a telecommunications system without the knowledge of the person making the communication. There are a number of exceptions to the prohibition against interception. For law enforcement purposes, the most significant are those related to stored communications and to interceptions under a warrant. The interception act is now expressed to exclude stored communications. The relevant amendment is sunseted and, unless some action is taken before 15 December 2005, the provisions will lapse. Currently, access to the content or substance of communications stored within the system is achieved by a general search warrant obtained under releMAIN COMMITTEE vant Commonwealth or state law which is executed under the provisions of part 13 of the Telecommunications Act, which prevents disclosure of content other than as prescribed. According to Mr Blunn, there has been no increase in the number of complaints about access to communications since the passage of the stored communications amendment. Prior to the amendment, it would appear that there were many very different views about the application of the interception act to stored communications. The review turned on the interpretation to be given to the words ‘passing over the telecommunications system’ and therefore to the issue of at what point a communication commenced and ceased passing over the system and ceased to be subject to the act. In relation to when a communication ceases passing over the system, there are at least three competing views: (a) when the message has been received-that is, read by the intended recipient, (b) when the message reaches the recipient’s receiving terminal and (c) when the message is stored, in the sense that it is at rest-that is, it is not being automatically processed by the telecommunications system and has reached the address from which it can be directly accessed by the intended recipient. Also, according to Mr Blunn, prior to the amendment to the interception act a number of agencies were acting on the understanding that, even then, the third view was the position at law and on that basis were accessing stored communications other than by an interception warrant. The amendment had the singular advantage of settling that issue, at least for the time being. If the amendment lapses by the operation of the sunset clause, nothing will have been settled and the previous unsatisfactory and uncertain position will be restored. This legislation not only extends for six months the provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act but also makes amendments to the interception act to (a) make the Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption eligible authorities for the purposes of the interception act, thereby allowing them to receive lawfully obtained intercepted material for the purpose of fulfilling their statutory obligation to investigate misconduct, including corruption; (b) enable the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption and the Queensland Corruption and Crime Commission to use lawfully obtained interception material for the purpose of their statutory function of investigating corrupt conduct and to use the material in proceedings under the Independent Commission Against Corruption Act 1988 and the Crime and Misconduct Act 2001 respectively; (c) enable the New South Wales Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission to use intercepted material for the purposes of fulfilling its statutory function in relation to the conduct of the Police Integrity Commission under the Police Integrity Commission Act 1996; (d) clarify that the expression ‘officer of a state’ includes all members of the police service of that state; and (e) make technical amendments arising from the enactment of the Legislative Instrument Act 2003. It is important that the current provisions be extended, allowing a thorough consideration of how best to regulate access to communications in the ever-changing world of technology advancement, especially in view of the increasingly uncertain world in which we now live. I look forward to the government’s response to the Blunn review and I commend this legislation to the House. MAIN COMMITTEE terception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Bill 2004. The amendment bill at hand, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005, provides for a six-month extension to provisions in the original bill, allowing law enforcement agencies to access stored communications without telecommunications interception warrants being issued under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The original amendment bill contained a 12-month sunset clause which would have seen the provisions cease operation in mid-December. The sunset clause was put in place to give the government time to consider the recommendations of an independent assessment of these changes. The bill before the House today adds a six-month extension to that sunset clause, giving the government additional time to consider a review of the regulations on access to stored communications. The review compiled by Anthony Blunn was presented at the introduction of the bill. It provides for a wide-ranging examination of where we are coming from, and where we are heading, in terms of regulating access to all forms of communication for investigative and security purposes. The purpose of the original bill was to rebalance our law and order needs with the everevolving communications sector. The technology we use to transmit communications is a very important aspect of the work of agencies charged with the security of this country. It will have profound ramifications for the investigative processes of our law enforcement agencies and those who seek to profit from crime. Mr Blunn’s wide-ranging report indicates that the government has, on the whole, struck the right balance between enhancing the powers of our law enforcement agencies and enhancing the privacy rights of citizens. But the government also needs to consider the supplementary issues Mr Blunn raised in his report. Hence the need for a six-month extension to the provisions of the original bill. By amending the original legislation the government is seeking to give our law enforcement agencies modern-day powers to tackle modern-day criminal activity. The amendments put forward by the government and reviewed by Mr Blunn update the powers of law enforcement agencies, giving them tools in the fight against crime and corruption. Specifically, the changes will benefit a number of anticorruption agencies, as the previous speaker, the member for Hughes, mentioned. These include the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission, the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission and the Victorian Office of Police Integrity, all of which use intercepted material in the investigation of corrupt conduct. For these agencies to do their jobs to the best of their ability, their investigative powers must keep pace with communications technology. Since the Telecommunications (Interception) Act commenced in 1979, more than 25 years ago, our methods of communicating have changed quite dramatically. When drafted, the act had only to cover live communications such as telephones, telexes and the like-where the content of communications was spoken or transmitted in real time and not able to be retained and stored in any manner, which, of course, is the case today. Accessing a stored electronic format of these communications was not possible in that era because messages could only be transmitted in a transient or temporary fashion. The review author, Tony Blunn, found that the language and detail of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 is becoming increasMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (11.13 Am)
theText: Last year I spoke on the Telecommunications (Iningly limited in accommodating new and emerging technologies through industry development and responding to the needs of security and law enforcement agencies. To paraphrase Mr Blunn, we face an entirely different scenario today, as any of us who use mobile telephones, pagers or palm pilots would know. We no longer have to wait for a wired message to come through. Today we have instant communications in the form of email, text messaging, picture messaging and paging. Using these modern-day communications, individuals can draft, edit, write and store messages and information before sending them to the recipient. This new technology has changed the way we work, interact and communicate with our friends, families and contacts, but it has also created an ever-widening implication for intelligence gathering, investigative practices and national security. Until the introduction of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Bill 2004, the interception of communications stored on new technologies such as text messages and emails was prohibited without a telecommunications interception warrant. Under the amended bill’s 12-month sunset clause, law enforcement agencies have been able to access stored communications with a standard search warrant rather than a telecommunications interception warrant, which has closed an ever-widening loophole in the legislation and helped keep pace with our ever-evolving communications technology. This is a crucial tool in fighting crime and terrorism, giving law enforcement agencies the power to access messages and other communications otherwise hidden from scrutiny. An extract from the Australian Strategic Policy Institute’s recent publication, Local Jihad: radical Islam and terrorism in Indonesia, illustrates the existing conundrum very well. Under the heading of ‘Measuring success against terrorism’, the report says in part: The most obvious standard measure of successand they are referring there to success against terrorismis the absence of a terrorist attack. The problem with relying on that measure is it’s based on past acts rather than future possibilities. Just because an attack has not happened yet does not mean that one isn’t currently being planned-9/11 and the London bombings are evidence of that fact. Being able to proactively prevent a terrorist attack or simply compile evidence for investigation or prosecution of a crime by accessing stored messages, such as emails and text messages, is a necessary evolution in our laws. One issue flagged in the Blunn report, which we as legislators must be mindful of, is the protection of privacy. Normally in these matters I would rather err on the side of privacy, but I recognise that we are in a much different environment today and we have to take on would be terrorists and the like with the best tools at our disposal. To some extent, privacy has to be compromised-hopefully, not on a long-term basis but certainly until we are through this very difficult time. Mr Blunn underlined the fact that privacy concerns must be a fundamental consideration when drafting legislation for security and law enforcement purposes. The government acknowledges that our ability to communicate freely and with a measure of privacy is one of the most fundamental tenets of our democracy. I am confident that this matter, along with the other recommendations in Mr Blunn’s review, will be at the forefront of the minister’s mind when considering the contents of the report. I think this extension is warranted, and I commend the bill to the Main Committee. MAIN COMMITTEE for Hinkler for his very thoughtful contribution, and I also thank the members for Hughes, Fisher and Gellibrand. I understand there were some unwarranted comments by the member for Fisher, who tends to want to flatter me, but other than that I am pleased at the general support for this measure. CanI just say that the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 regulates the use of interception and intercepted material by law enforcement, national security and a number of dedicated anticorruption agencies, and the regulatory regime ensures that there is a balance between protecting the privacy of those who use Australia’s telecommunications systems and the legitimate need to fight organised crime, threats to national security and corruption. This bill will of course continue for a further six months the provisions that deal with stored communications, pending our deliberations on the recommendations of the report in the Blunn review, presented to the House earlier in this debate. I thank the member for Gellibrand for her indication of support for this extension and her acknowledgment that these are complex issues and that the time to implement them ought to be available. The bill also includes important amendments to enhance the way in which anticorruption agencies are able to access and use lawfully obtained intercepted material. The bill really does send a very strong message that corrupt conduct by persons holding public positions is simply unacceptable and backs this message up with enhanced investigatory tools for anticorruption agencies. The anticorruption agencies, of course, that will benefit from the changes include the newly created Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. Other agencies that will benefit are the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission and the New South Wales Inspector of Police Integrity Commission. There is one issue in which I think some inappropriate observations were drawn by the member for Gellibrand about the amendments in relation to the Victorian Office of Police Integrity. The amendments here will only commence if the Victorian government legislates to provide satisfactory accountability and oversight arrangements for the office. It is important to understand the issue that has been a very live issue here where the Victorian government resisted appropriate independent scrutiny of some potential use-forinterception material that was to be given to the Ombudsman with one title but to be supervised by the Ombudsman simply wearing another cap. For us that was totally unacceptable. It would be unacceptable to any fair-minded person that Caesar should investigate Caesar, yet that is what Victoria had in mind, and it persisted. Victoria could have had in place effective telecommunications interception for its police anticorruption agency if it had been prepared to put in place effective, independent monitoring of those arrangements. I would not want to say in relation to this measure that Victoria has backed down; I would want to say that Victoria now intends that its measures will be compliant with a regime that I think any fair-minded person in this House and certainly in the Senate would expect. In fact, I think I would have been seen to be derelict in my duties if I had been prepared to see the interception powers used-powers which are very intrusive-without adequate independent verification and scrutiny. I am surprised that Victoria, which preaches in relation to these matters-and I notice it was a Victorian member, the member for Gellibrand, who MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Ruddock (Berowra
theText: Attorney-General) (11.22 am)-in reply-I thank the member
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Seems To Be On Side With The Victorian Attorney
theText: General, Mr Hulls-would want a situationwhere there was inadequate scrutiny. SoI am disappointed that she suggests that this bill is in some way a backdown; it is not. These measures will only operate for Victoria when they have put in place the appropriate independent scrutiny. SoI make the point: the amendments in relation to the Victorian Office of Police Integrity will only commence if the Victorian government legislates to provide satisfactory accountability and oversight arrangements. That has always been our position. I am glad that Victoria has seen fit to come to the party. The bill will also ensure that intercepted material may be used in the investigation of misconduct by members of state and territory police forces by ensuring that state police fall within the definition of an officer of the state. The anticorruption measures of this bill indicate very clearly our commitment to fight against corruption. I commend the bill to the chamber. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Second Reading Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock: That this bill be now read a second time. iff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 but also to address issues of a critical nature going to the governance of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the foundation bill governing the critical role of the Australian Customs Service, the Customs Act 1901 as amended. As members of the House are aware, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 by ensuring that customs duty is not payable on goods that are described as of a non-commercial character being brought in by non-Australian citizens who are family members of participants who are attending the Commonwealth Games in Melbourne in 2006. The bill is not contentious, because it exempts the imposition of a customs duty on goods. Any exemption from a customs duty or other impost, whether a tax, levy or other instrument of government revenue, is always welcome. Obviously, the loser, if one can call them that, is the long-suffering Australian taxpayer. Indeed, the Attorney-General and member for Berowra, the Hon. Philip Ruddock, said, in his second reading speech on this bill, on Wednesday, 14 September 2005: It is expected that Commonwealth Games participants and officials will bring with them a variety of goods that are to be used in a non-commercial manner. These will include give-aways, hospitality samples and other consumables that will be used for team promotion and for cultural and hospitality activities. Clearly, the intention of this legislation is to recognise that the financial benefit to Australia of the imposition of a customs duty on such non-commercial goods imported into Australia is outweighed by the national policy impact of the impost during such an auspicious event as the Commonwealth Games. Members of the House see in an instant the wisdom of exempting such goods from customs duty, yet how does this parliament regard the situation of goods upon which a duty is prescribed under the customs import regulations and which are clearly imported for commercial profit but which are systematically hidden from the Australian CusMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Telecommunications Interception Amendment Stored Communications And Other Measures Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (11.29 Am)
theText: I rise not only to speak in support of the Customs Tartoms Service with the sole and substantial intent of defrauding the Commonwealth of its revenue? What do members of the House and the general public say about those cheats who deliberately import, by the container load, shipment after shipment of goods, deliberately failing to declare the quantity or understating their price with the sole and substantial purpose of defrauding the Commonwealth of its revenue by refusing to pay the prescribed amount of duty? May I speak for all in this parliament and all law-abiding Australian citizens in saying that no-one likes a cheat. No-one likes to see two importers of goods upon which an import duty is payable, one abiding by the law and the other not abiding by the law, and then see the wrongdoer not only profit as to his or her criminal and civil liability conduct but also compete unfairly against the other importer who is paying his or her customs duties and declaring the goods to the Customs Service, Quarantine and other agencies-in short, doing the right thing. With these precursors in mind, I wish to bring to the attention of members a reported judgment in the Supreme Court of New South Wales, Common Law Division, involving the CEO of Customsv Ozzy Tyre and Tube Pty Ltd and Lorene Khamis [2005, NSWC at 948] before Justice Stephen Rothman. This judgment was handed down only three weeks ago, on 25 September 2005. I bring this case to the parliament’s attention today because of the size of the sums and the audacity of the defendants in attempting to defraud the Commonwealth of its revenue and otherwise evade Commonwealth law. Ms Lorene Khamis is a director of Ozzy Tyre and Tube Pty Ltd. The statistics of this case are quite staggering: (1) eighteen shipments of motor vehicle tyres, wheels and parts from 18 December 1998 to about 24 March 2000, (2) a finding by the Supreme Court on the total of unpaid duties, equalling a reported $255,000 and (3) the total of fines imposed by the Supreme Court being a staggering $3,237,000. However, the case does not end there. What is even more staggering is a fact reported in the Australian on 26 September 2005 in a news article by Vanda Carson entitled ‘Judge slams hot-rod deal’: A director of Australia’s largest hot-rod wheel and tyre supplier has been fined $3.5 million for smuggling car accessories into the country and defrauding Customs. … … … Justice Stephen Rothman lamented the fact that the plea-bargain-deal allowed her to avoid punishment. Customs chief executive John Mansfield has agreed not to pursue Ms Khamis or her company for the $3.5 million provided she pays $255,000 in unpaid duties. The judge said there would be no deterrence from breaking the law if importers caught evading duties were only punished by having to pay the duty they should have paid in the first place. Before getting to the heart of this deplorable situation, I wish to remind the parliament of the threefold primary roles of the Australian Customs Service. I cite page 14 of the Australian Customs Service annual report of 2003-04 under the title ‘Vision and Roles’. Customs has three principal roles: to facilitate trade and the movement of people across the Australian border while protecting the community and maintaining compliance with Australian law to collect customs revenue efficiently; and to administer specific industry schemes and trade measures. MAIN COMMITTEE Let us now apply the outcomes of the Ozzy Tyres case to the three primary roles of the ACS. Has the ACS in the Ozzy Tyres case facilitated trade and the movement of people across the Australian border while protecting the community and maintaining compliance with Australian law? I say no. Yes, the Customs chief executive officer did commence civil litigation against those defrauding Customs and the Australian taxpayer of our revenue and, yes, the Customs chief executive officer did obtain a judgment from the Supreme Court of New South Wales. However, what is inexcusable is the fact that, after the judgment three weeks ago, he let these smugglers go. He let these persons convicted of their civil liabilities go, releasing them of a liability to the Australian taxpayer of some $3.5 million. Let us go to the second prescribed role of Customs-that is, to collect customs revenue efficiently. AgainI ask the House whether it believes, in light of this Supreme Court of New South Wales judgment, that the ACS has collected customs revenue efficiently, including those fines and penalties accruing from failure by persons liable to pay that revenue. AgainI say no. The ACS, as agent for the Commonwealth, was owed $3.5 million in fines and simply allowed the defrauding smugglers to walk away. What does that all say about the governance of the ACS? Again, I can only reiterate the words of Justice Rothman, who with total clarity notes the complete collapse of any final fear and deterrence in the hearts of the wrongdoers. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say to the Attorney-General today what this judgment means for community protection and for compliance with Australian law. First, the action of the Customs chief executive officer in reaching this sweetheart deal with the director of Ozzy Tyres and with Ozzy Tyres as a body corporate is one of the most destructive decisions in the history of the Australian Customs Service, in my opinion. Far from protecting the Australian community, including those legitimate participants in the Australian tyre retail and distribution industry, the deal struck between the Customs CEO, Ozzy Tyres and one director of that company has dealt a fatal blow to the confidence of legitimate importers of any kind. In other words, those who do the right thing will be abandoned, while those who smuggle, cheat and defraud will walk away without any final punishment. In short, the message is out: do the wrong thing and you will get away with it; do the right thing and you will be flogged. Put in simple terms, wrong is right; right is wrong. For several years Ozzy Tyres deliberately imported goods with the sole intention of undermining the customs revenue collection system. When they were eventually caught, they pleaded that they could not pay the penalty and were simply let off. Let me now quote from the tyre industry journal, Australian Tyre Dealer. On page 13 of edition no. 4 of volume 14 of Australian Tyre Dealer-the August-September 2005 issue-is a full one-page glossy advertisement for Ozzy Tyres, titled ‘Ozzy Tyres wants you’. This advertisement describes Ozzy Tyres as ‘one of Australia’s leading tyre and wheel companies’. The advertisement goes on to boast that ‘Ozzy Tyres prides itself on only dealing with trusted and respected wheel manufacturers and has exclusive supply agreements with some of the biggest wheel companies in the world.’ Allow me to bring to the attention of the Attorney-General the impact of Ozzy Tyres on its competitors. As a result of Ozzy Tyres’s conviction for being a smuggler and a defrauder of Commonwealth revenue and its breach of several sections of the Customs Act-too numerous MAIN COMMITTEE to mention here today-Ozzy Tyres has radically undercut the price of its competitor distributors. ourable member opposite would consent under the standing orders to answer a question. ment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005. While I know that the member opposite feels very passionately about the subject he is currently addressing, I wonder whether he would be able to show us how the matter of Ozzy Tyres in some way comes within the purview of the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005, given the fact that the purpose of this bill is to allow entry of certain goods relating to the Commonwealth Games. duty is not payable on goods that are described as being of a non-commercial character. I am talking about a case that was brought to my attention last week by a constituent who is very concerned about the implications for the tyre industry across Australia. It is a very important public interest matter. I appreciate that my colleague and friend the member for Fisher was not here at the start of my contribution, so I will make that concession. But this is a very important matter which I believe is germane to the debate, and I would like the Attorney General, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to follow up this particular case. I am afraid that Ozzy Tyres effectively got off scot-free in this particular matter. It is to the detriment of other operators in the industry that these people can just continue to operate and not pay the ultimate penalty, which they should. Perhaps if the member listens to what more I have to say, he will appreciate the relevance of it. I would hope that he would advocate on behalf of the concerns of my constituents and all those honest, law-abiding people in the tyre industry across Australia to see that this sort of thing does not happen again. Quite plainly, the principal in this particular matter is continuing to operate, and that is at the expense of all those law abiding citizens who are operating within the industry. order or do you have a question? deign to answer a further question. to be kept short. and I would like to see it in the other chamber as well. My question to the member for Lowe is that, while I can understand the significance of what he is telling us, how does he justify the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 to be the appropriate forum to draw to the attention of the Attorney-General the serious matters that he is currently addressing in the chamber? In short, Ozzy have profited by their dishonesty and their breaches of Australian Commonwealth law. The damage to the tyre industry in Australia could not be more catastrophic. Ozzy’s competitors have been wrongly accused of forcing prices up. They have lost market share and ultimately gone into bankruptcy or insolvency. As a direct consequence, the legitimate retailer and distributor channels are being seriously undermined and Australian industry is being destroyed. This type of conduct is part of the grey marketing scourge being visited upon Australia today. Is this what the CEO of the Australian Customs Service calls protecting the Australian community and maintaining compliance with Australian law? The border protection of Australian industry in matters such as the Ozzy Tyre scandal is a matter that cries for justice. In this case there is a desperate need for the ACS to be fully staffed and equipped to monitor and prosecute those smugglers and other wrongdoers. Australian industry deserves lawful protection and I am sure the government wants to do something about it. Grey marketing is a serious matter. Figures are scant but it is estimated that only three per cent of container terminals are actually inspected by Customs-that is, 97 per cent of all containers are not inspected. What does this say about smuggling and the importation of dangerous goods in the terrorist environment that we are experiencing at the moment? Australia is currently a wide open target for grey marketing. In the Ozzy Tyre case we have the benefit of one finding of 18 smuggled shipments. It is hard enough for the plaintiff lawyers to gather the evidence, issue the subpoenas, build the case and lead to a successful finding of civil liability; it is lamentable that the CEO of Customs could let the convicted wrongdoers off the hook entirely, calling upon them to pay no more than what they were bound to pay anyway. speaker: Mr Murphy
theText: Let me continue. By simply refusing to pay customs duties, Ozzy havestock for those who would attempt to defraud the Commonwealth of its revenue and make more and more audacious breaches. ‘You must pay your taxes and duties, but only if you want to.’ That is the message. Equally, the message is that if you do not want to pay taxes and duties then it is okay. That is what I am concerned about. I fear that the government’s response to the New South Wales Supreme Court’s judgment will be to refer this matter to some committee seeking amendments to the Customs Act or some other legislation-because this is how it is usually done. Such a problem is usually referred to some committee so the government is seen to be doing something when in fact nothing might change. I want to see something change in this particular case. The CEO of Customs in this case had obtained a conviction. There was nothing more to do than enforce the court’s judgment. If the defendants could not pay then bankrupt them. That would leave the legitimate businesses, who are doing the right thing, to trade with a measure of relief and in the knowledge that there was some protection of their interests. However, sadly this is not the case. I urge the Attorney-General to take action to ensure that justice is done in this case. A good start would be to examine why only civil litigation was commenced and whether the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions has been briefed for possible criminal action against the defendants. A second thing the Attorney-General can do is to call in his CEO of Customs and have him show cause for conduct that has the Australian tyre industry tearing its hair out in despair at the moment. I am advised that the arrangement between the CEO of the ACS and Ozzy Tyres is ‘good at law’ and still stands. This is an appalling precedent and a disgraceful outcome for Australian industry and all those Aussie battling family businesses that this government purportedly represents. The law in this area is inadequate in that it permits only a pecuniary punishment. I recommend that the Attorney-General expand the range of permissible penalties, including incarceration and community service orders. In this case, yet again, we have a situation where a director has placed the assets out of reach of her creditors, arrogantly pleading that she is impecuniousbeing a family business-meaning that she simply cannot pay the $3.5 million due to the taxpayers. Let me tell you that by her conduct she has ruined other honest industry operators. That is why I am bringing this to the attention of the parliament. Her conduct is selfish. If she or the company cannot pay it should be placed into administration or made insolvent. Why should Ozzy’s competitors and the Australian taxpayer pay for a convicted criminal and civilly liable conduct? Why should we jointly and severally permit these serious breaches of customs law to be rewarded whilst Ozzy continues trading and expanding its business? How is it that Ozzy is able to place full-page advertisements in major journals, such as the Australian Tyre Dealer, boasting that it is so successful that it is expanding and calling for more franchises, when it is supposed to be impecunious? This is the point I am making: these people are clearly corrupt. In concluding, I caution on a disturbing point. As I mentioned, grey marketing is rampant in a multitude of import industries, particularly high-volume consumables. Examples also include computer media such as floppy disks, CDs and other computer components. Other industry examples include cosmetics and clothes. The list is almost endless. All these types of goods are imported largely without rigorous regulation. Equally, there is an active industry in the recycling of import companies that are fly-by-night businesses and operators, making it MAIN COMMITTEE difficult to prosecute any one entity. On behalf of my constituents and people in this industry and similar industries, I am demanding greater regulatory control. I urge the Attorney-General to demonstrate leadership and to govern by taking the matter of Australian industry protection seriously and beginning to punish those who flagrantly abuse our customs laws while destroying Australian industry. I further urge that there be an increase in Customs forces, with particular reference to container searching and inspection so as to increase the absolute number of containers searched from the current statistics of three per cent. I ask my friend and colleague to take the circumstances of that case back to the Attorney-General, who might not be aware of it, and ask him to follow that up with the CEO of Customs. It has certainly left a very sour taste not only with my constituent in the tyre industry but also with all his colleagues in the association that represents the tyre industry. They would like something to be done about it. I am sure they will appreciate me bringing it to the attention of the parliament, and I hope that something good comes from this, notwithstanding the issue-which I understand-raised by the member for Fisher in relation to its direct relevance to the bill before the House. toms Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005. Referring to the remarks made by the honourable member for Lowe, I think the appropriate minister is probably the Minister for Justice and Customs. He would religiously read the Hansard, but I would like to make the point at the outset that, because I have a high regard for the member for Lowe, I did not take a point of order on relevance on this. I could see that he felt very strongly about the subject and, even though-as you pointed out, Mr Deputy Speaker-there could well be better or more appropriate forums for him to raise those matters, we chose not to take a point of order on this occasion. Next year, starting from 15 March, Australians will once again relish the chance to show the world what we are made of. That of course is the date of the opening ceremony of the 2006 Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Melbourne. Representatives of the 71 Commonwealth nations will converge on the capital of Victoria for 11 days of physical competition in pursuits such as athletics and swimming through to basketball, boxing, cycling, shooting, rugby sevens, weight-lifting and so on. But international sporting events are today much more than just sports events. They are held alongside cultural extravaganzas and festivals that celebrate the diversity of the world. The Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 aims to bring about a very sensible situation which will remove duty and tariff barriers that would potentially detract from the celebratory aspect of the Commonwealth Games. Honourable members will be interested to know that the bill will provide duty-free entry to Australia of items that are of no real commercial value but that are brought into our country by non-Australian members of the Commonwealth Games family for purposes related to this sporting and cultural celebration. These goods would include those needed for cultural and hospitality functions, samples, promotional items and also giveaways. Goods such as alcohol, tobacco, motor vehicle parts, television cameras and radio broadcasting equipment will not be eligible for the concession. Honourable members would be aware that Australia is not new to hosting international sporting events. For instance, Melbourne hosted the Olympic Games in 1956, the CommonMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Customs Tariff Amendment Commonwealth Games Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (11.52 Am)
theText: I am pleased to be able to join the debate on the Cuswealth Games were held in Brisbane in 1982 and the world saw Australia through new eyes when we hosted the Sydney 2000 Olympics-and it is really hard to believe that five years have now elapsed since that wonderful event. Australians showed the world at Sydney, and also at Melbourne and Brisbane, what we can do when we work together, and the world was impressed. The world was impressed not only at the smooth operation of those events, particularly the Olympics, but also by our people-our volunteers, our bus drivers, cabbies and general citizens-who all shared the patriotism and excitement that the games brought. Who will ever forget the words uttered by the then President of the IOC, Juan Samaranch, when he described Sydney in 2000 as ‘the best games ever’? With Australians now counting down the days to the Melbourne Commonwealth Games, the government is determined to reduce the legislative restrictions that may in any way hamper these games from becoming an equal runaway success. While the desire to be triumphant on the international scene is an overwhelming one, the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 will not-and I stress will not-usher in a free-for-all import environment for anyone to abuse. I cited a moment ago a number of items that will not be eligible for the relaxed provisions. These provisions outlined in the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 are similar to provisions created for the Sydney Olympic Games and also the Paralympics. The Paralympics in 2000 were also an outstanding success. These provisions will remain in force for a period of six months from 1 January, a period that allows plenty of time for our visitors to be able to bring their items into Australia to prepare for the March event. The Australian government are proud of our achievements at Sydney and we are committed to providing a platform for similar success at Melbourne. Melburnians are mad about their sports and that in-built vigour is already generating community-wide aspirations for a successful Commonwealth Games in 2006. The Australian government feel the same energy, and this bill further indicates our strong commitment to the success of the Melbourne event. Customs laws include a number of pre-existing concessions for personal effects and equipment that are directly required by officials and athletes involved in the games itself, but while in Australia these athletes, coaches and family members from the various Commonwealth countries will also have first-hand experience of our hospitality, our laid-back, comfortable way of life, our tolerance of others and our determination to put on a cracking good show. AndI do hope that many of those Commonwealth Games visitors take advantage of the opportunity of travelling to Queensland, to the Sunshine Coast and to other parts of our nation to appreciate that Australia has a lot more to offer than simply being an outstanding games organiser and an outstanding sporting nation. I see the Attorney-General in the chamber. In an earlier speech I said that, in my view, he is one of the best ministers in the government. He is here, his time is important, so I will not continue to talk at length. I just stress that the provisions of the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 will help achieve the outcome the government seeks and will help ensure that the Melbourne Commonwealth Games are a real success. I am very pleased to be able to commend the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 to the chamber. of the member for Fisher. I thank him for his generous remarks. I do not think they are deMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Customs Tariff Amendment Commonwealth Games Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Ruddock (Berowra
theText: Attorney-General) (11.59 am)-I did hear earlier the remarksserved, and I am sure members of the opposition do not think they are deserved, but I value his role as a constructive barracker and appreciate the spirit in which the remarks were offered. The Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 is an important measure, and I am glad that it is being supported. Obviously, the amendments to the Customs Tariff Act to provide duty-free entry for goods for use in, or for purposes related to, the Melbourne Commonwealth Games will be an important adjunct to the success of the games. The goods will include giveaways and hospitality samples. Concessions will not apply to alcohol and tobacco products or extend to importations of a commercial nature. The existing provisions under the customs legislation relating to personal effects and temporary importations will also be available for the purposes relating to the games. I would have thought the opportunities to speak on this legislation would have been fairly limited, but I am told that the member for Lowe was able to range quite widely on customs matters generally. I should just take the opportunity to say in relation to his comments about the extent to which containers are examined in Australia that I am surprised, given the spirit in which this bill is being considered and because of the security situation, that he would not have acknowledged that container examination issues are taken very seriously by this government. The inspection of containers in Australia compares very favourably with the quantum and percentages that are effected in the United States and in Canada. Very extensive container examination facilities have been installed in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide and Fremantle. In addition, I am told that the customs container examination process is among the world’s best in volume, speed, cost and system capability and that more than 98 per cent of containers are back at the wharf within the free storage period. So it is a good news story, and that ought to be appreciated. From time to time issues are raised in relation to customs matters. The member for Lowe wanted to raise a matter which is before the courts. I imagine that, if there were relevant issues that ought to be put, it would be more appropriate to have approached the Comptroller of Customs and his officers to put a view. He could have done that. I am advised that on this issue the Australian Government Solicitor and Customs are aware of the matter. The case does raise quite complex issues. I understand that the presiding judge commented on the lack of alternatives to the outcome in this case, which has arisen only recently. My colleague the Minister for Justice and Customs will be briefed on the issues raised and the government will consider whether changes to the law are required. I do not know that it needed to take up the full amount of time that it did. I would prefer in a matter of this sort that the bill proceeds expeditiously. I am grateful for the support that has been given for the bill’s passage, and I commend the bill to the chamber. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment. MAIN COMMITTEE Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee Report Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Barresi: That the House take note of the report. ing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation report Making it work was adjourned I mentioned that these concerns are the very concerns that the Transport Workers Union made so clear during its campaign to heighten awareness of the plight of independent contractors that has prompted action on my part. In an effort to put a set of rules in place that will allow independent contractors a fair go at negotiating fair agreement with large organisations, the member for Hunter and I have co-sponsored a private member’s bill that will amend the Trade Practices Act to allow small businesses to access collective bargaining. Just because independent contractors are treated like business operators does not mean they carry with them all the clout that would ordinarily be associated with a business operator. It is important that the Trade Practices Act reflects this. Already this year we have had amendments to the Trade Practices Act that do nothing but exacerbate the problem that people like the transport workers I met in Canberra are currently experiencing. Their right to have a union collectively bargain with large companies on their behalf has been removed under the guise of reform. This government says that these workers-and at the end of the day they are workers, not necessarily just business operators-have the right to negotiate, but bear in mind that many are often forced to negotiate with the large and sometimes internationally based organisations for whom they work. It is like asking a goldfish to negotiate with a shark and expecting that the goldfish will have a fair chance of not being eaten. It is a ridiculous expectationone that everyone knows is well beyond reality-which contractors such as these transport workers and other independent contractors face on a daily basis. The private member’s bill that I co-sponsored seeks to rebalance the process by allowing small business operators to collectively bargain. I know that members opposite may claim that the recent decision of the ACCC means that in truth it is still permissible, but these are exceptions rather than any general rule. The private member’s bill seeks to strengthen the bargaining position of small businesses by allowing them to get together to bargain as a collective without the cumbersome, time-consuming and inefficient authorisation processes that currently exist through the ACCC. This is the sort of thing that, quite frankly, small businesses want. This is the sort of thing that would help them out immediately, and it would certainly be a greater weight off their minds than whether or not they can unfairly sack somebody without repercussions. I congratulate the Labor members of the committee for their dissenting report, but I also congratulate all members of the committee on the amount of common ground that was found. I look forward to the government taking these matters seriously by adopting a number of the recommendations that were agreed to. Dr EMERSON (Rankin) (12.08 pm)-I indicate my support for the private member’s bill that the members for Hunter and Werriwa are moving. It is soundly based in practical terms MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Customs Tariff Amendment Commonwealth Games Bill 2005

speaker: Mr Hayes (Werriwa) (12.04 Pm)
theText: Before debate on the House of Representatives Standand philosophically because it is based on our assertion of the right of all working Australians to be able to bargain collectively. We certainly know that independent contractors in the transport industry are very hard working Australians. The irony, of course, is that the government is amending the Trade Practices Act to allow small businesses that supply products to large businesses-most particularly small firms supplying, for example, large retail chains-to bargain collectively. It seems to me that, if it is good for the government to do that in relation to suppliers to large retailers, surely it is similarly important and right that workers in the transport industry have the same basic right. It astonishes me that, day after day, week after week and year after year, the government claims that every Australian has the right to bargain collectively. This is just untrue. It has been untrue since 1996. Yet the former industrial relations minister, now the Minister for Health and Ageing, told a Vietnamese worker who was locked out in the Morris McMahon dispute that, if they wanted a collective agreement, they had every right to ask for it. What he did not say is that the employer has every right to refuse it. That is the truth of the matter. Those working Australians who seek to bargain collectively and who seek a collective agreement have nothing more than a right to ask the employer to agree to that. The employer, under that legislation, has a right to say no. I say that a right vetoed is no right at all. I will not speak for long on this committee report entitled Making it work. I do want to commend the member for Gorton, the Deputy Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation. The main report is of very substantial value, I must say; the dissenting report, even more so. Point 1.3 says: It was accepted by all Committee members that there were genuine independent contractorsand we all accept thatbut an inordinate amount of evidence suggested that many workers were being forced to work as so called independent contractors in order to avoid taxation or traditional employer responsibilities, such as superannuation contributions or workers’ compensation insurance. This is just another case in this industry of the government using the tax system-using whatever it possibly can-to encourage people to set themselves up as independent contractors where, in many cases, they are not. A lot of revenue is being forgone as a result of that, but so obsessed is this government with busting unions and busting collective arrangements that it is prepared to allow the taxpayer to bear the burden of that. I commend the member for Gorton, and I commend this report. with some very important matters. I would like to add some brief remarks to those that have been made by the member for Rankin and the member for Werriwa. This is a matter of growing importance in our economy, with a growing incidence of independent contractors and labour hire employees. One of the great questions is how this phenomenon is being driven. Is it being driven by individual contractors seeking increased flexibility in their working lives and in their business arrangements and therefore incorporating themselves and seeking to work as contractors? Alternatively, is it being driven by companies seeking increased flexibility from their employees, asking that they incorporate themselves and therefore changing the employment relationship so that these people are no longer technically employees although they are, MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Bowen (Prospect) (12.12 Pm)
theText: Making it work is an important report which dealsof course, employees in the real world? Both elements are at play here. This happens both ways. One of the big questions is: what is the overriding factor? I have to say that the majority report is disappointing in that it does not make a more satisfactory distinction between genuine independent contractors who deserve support in their arrangements and what are in effect labour hire or contracting arrangements which are driven by the employer to gain more flexibility from the employee in a way which is not necessarily to the employee’s benefit. This report does make some useful recommendations in relation to people who are genuine independent contractors. This is a growing sector of the economy, and we need to do everything we can to support these people. In particular, I refer to recommendation 13, which calls on the Office of Small Business to develop more resources to support independent contractors in ‘setting up a small business, financial and reporting requirements, dispute resolution options and business management practices’.
