As I say, I think the biggest inadequacy in the majority report is its failure to deal in any meaningful way with problems facing labour hire employees, many of whom only work in such circumstances because it is the only form of employment available to them. Working for a labour hire company can be a very precarious existence. Between 75 and 95 per cent of labour hire workers are casually employed. Of course, this means that they can have very irregular hours of work, no sick leave and no annual leave. Some would say they get a higher hourly rate. Sometimes that is true and sometimes it is not. The minority report makes a very interesting recommendation in relation to the registration of labour hire companies. The report notes: The Committee received evidence from labour hire companies and unions suggesting the need to register labour hire companies. It was contended that many labour hire companies were not competent to be legally recognised as labour hire companies and therefore it was considered that a register be established to ensure that business conducted by labour hire companies meet an appropriate industry standard. The most interesting thing out of that is that some of those submissions were made by labour hire companies themselves. I dare suggest that the labour hire companies that made those recommendations to the committee are the genuine ones that are sick of their good name being sullied by the operators out there who exploit their workers and give the other labour companies a bad name. I am not saying that all labour hire companies are a bad thing. Employment by a labour hire company suits some people. There is no doubt about that. But some labour hire companies are exploiting their employees, and the more reputable labour hire companies are sick and tired of their good name being sullied. So they, together with trade unions, have suggested that a register of labour hire companies be established. That is a recommendation taken up by the minority on this committee but not, alas, by the majority. I do not think that the majority report deals anywhere near adequately with that issue. The Victorian parliament’s Economic Development Committee found that one quarter of Victorian businesses use labour hire companies and three per cent of Australian employees are employed by labour hire companies. So this is an important matter. Of course, we have seen growing flexibility in the Australian labour market over the last few years, and that is not a bad thing; it is a very good thing. But we need to ensure that labour hire companies operate in such a manner that the rights and conditions of their employees are protected. MAIN COMMITTEE In relation to independent contractors, I referred earlier to the matter of whether an independent contractor makes the move to that form of employment for reasons to do with the flexibility of the employer or of the employee. I was drawn to the submission to the inquiry from the Transport Workers Union which talked about the degree of practical independence of most independent contractors in the transport industry. Of course the transport industry is dominated by owner-drivers or, to use another form of words, independent contractors. The Transport Workers Union pointed out that the degree of independence enjoyed by most owner-operators in the day-to-day exercise of their business is minimal, to say the least. They said, for example, that most owner-drivers-in fact, they say almost all, without exceptionperform work for a single transport operator. They perform work at the behest of that operator, in accordance with very specific priorities including specific delivery pick-up priorities set by the directors and management of that operator. They are usually required to hold themselves available to perform work for a single contractor, thus rendering them unavailable for anyone else. They take direction from that operator on a day-to-day basis, as if they were employees of the operator. They are required to paint or otherwise mark their vehicles in their operator’s colours and/or insignia and they have little or no power to set the price-rather, they take the price they are given. In other words, anybody seeing a truck or a van drive past with the colours or logo of a courier company-or some other sort of transport operator delivering goods on behalf of that operator-would, if they thought about it, quite fairly assume that the individual driving that truck or courier van was an employee of the company. In the vast majority of cases they are not an employee; they are independent contractors who happen to work for only that company and are required by that company to work for only that company. They work a roster set by that company, their days and hours of work are determined solely by that company and they have a payment rate set by that company. They do not negotiate with the employer, the parent company, and say, ‘Here’s how much we’ll deliver your parcels for.’ The rate is set by the company and all the contractors get paid exactly the same rate. There are no independent negotiations. There is no force of supply and demand to say, ‘HereI am, an extra-flexible individual who is able to work for a transport company and I will do it as an independent contractor.’ They are in effect, if not in law, employees of that company, of course. This brings me to representation. There are 12,000 Transport Workers Union members in New South Wales who are independent contractors. They, like many people in many other industries, like to be represented in negotiations. If they were employees, despite the government’s proposed workplace relations changes, they could of course be represented by their trade union. Until recently as independent contractors they could be represented by their trade union, but this government is taking that right away. The only possible explanation for that is ideology. There is no explanation in terms of rational policy, there is no explanation in terms of rational economic thought; there is an explanation in terms of ideology. This committee received evidence regarding the actions of the government in limiting the right of independent contractors to engage a trade union to bargain on their behalf. The government is fine with independent contractors being represented by bodies such as the Pharmacy Guild or the various players associations across the country-the cricket players’ association, the football players’ association. That is not prohibited by law, but this government is opposing the right of these people to be represented by a group which happens to MAIN COMMITTEE be a trade union. We hear often that this government is in favour of choice, unless you are an independent contractor who wishes to be represented by a trade union. In that case you have no choice. Recently, together with other honourable members-the honourable member for Werriwa might have been there-I attended a seminar in Parliament House put on by the Transport Workers Union where independent contractors talked about how they would like their trade union to represent them. To their credit, some government members came and listened. I know the members for O’Connor and Gilmore were there. They heard the cases put by the independent contractors who said, ‘We work very hard, we need somebody to stand up for us and we choose the Transport Workers Union.’ Nobody could fail to be moved by some of those cases. These people work very long hours for rates of pay which are not high by any standard. They are simply seeking to have somebody represent them in their negotiations. What is wrong with an independent contractor choosing a body which also represents employees to represent them in negotiations over contracts? This government has refused that to happen. One of the most moving speeches at that seminar was, I thought, from the wife of an independent contractor who told the audience that she already rarely sees her husband. She does the bookwork for the operation and on a day-today basis they are trying to make their small business work. They wanted to get into small business and they are happy to do that; all they want is a bit of help in negotiations, some support from their union. I do not think that is an unreasonable request but apparently the government thinks it is an unreasonable request and that is a sad thing. Moving on, the committee makes some useful recommendations in the field of occupational health and safety, such as recommendation 7, which suggests that the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations and the Workplace Relations Ministers Council develop initiatives to achieve greater understanding and that they more clearly delineate responsibilities among various governments for occupational health and safety for independent contractors-and, of course, amongst various agencies within the government. I support that recommendation. Occupational health and safety is a very important factor for everybody, including independent contractors. In conclusion, this is an important report but it is a disappointing report in many respects. The majority report does not make an adequate distinction between genuine independent contractors, small business people who want to make a contribution to the economy and people who feel that, simply to make a living, they are being forced into incorporating small business and into becoming independent contractors. I would regard labour hire employees as a completely separate category. These employees might pack shelves, work on the wharves or carry out a whole range of manual work. They are not independent contractors in any meaningful sense of the word. They are casual employees who can only get jobs at labour hire firms. They work long hours and do not get great rates of pay to compensate them for the loss of sick pay, holiday pay et cetera. They are not independent contractors in any meaningful sense of the words. I think the majority report could have dealt with the issue of labour hire employees much better and made much better recommendations on support and protection for genuine labour hire workers. Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned. MAIN COMMITTEE Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Howard: That this House: (1) notes that 15 August 2005 (VP Day) marks 60 years since the Japanese surrender which ended World War II; (2) recalls with profound gratitude the heroic achievements and sacrifices of those Australians who served in the defence forces during the war, as well as those who contributed on the civilian front; (3) particularly remembers the thousands of Australians who lost their lives or were wounded in the conflict, and especially recalls the suffering of so many Australians taken as prisoners of war; (4) whilst never forgetting those who suffered during World War II, acknowledges the strength and importance of the post World War II relationship between Australia and Japan; and (5) resolves that Australia’s efforts should always be directed to ensuring that a conflict of that magnitude never occurs again. moment for Australia as a nation and also for Australians as a people. Japan’s surrender to the allied forces did not only mark the end of World War II; it also heralded a new era for Australia. It saw an era too where we were reconciled with the Japanese nation, which has gone on to be our greatest trading partner since. That having been said, it was a very testing time for this country. We were a young, vibrant nation. We had faced and overcome enemy attacks on our own soil. For the first time in our history mainland Australia was bombed by enemy forces. Shipping was attacked by midget submarines in Sydney Harbour, Townsville was bombed and, of course, there were the infamous raids on Darwin, and there were raids right across Northern Australia-80 of them in all. Our people faced the prospect, though we did not know it at the time, of a possible invasion through Papua New Guinea. It was a time of great uncertainty and fear. We are geographically isolated, with a huge border to secure and a very small population. As I said, Australia was a young nation, and it certainly faced its biggest threat. At the start of the Pacific war we were barely 40 years old as a nation, and we were about to be bloodied for the second time in 27 years-or, if you want to go back to 1939, when World War II started, we were going to be bloodied for the second time in 25 years. If it had not been for the heroic and sustained fighting that took place throughout the Pacific-including on the Malay Peninsula; in Singapore; in Timor; on the Kokoda Track; at the Battle of the Coral Sea; later, with our American colleagues, at the Battle of Midway; in the Solomons; on Savo Island; at Milne Bay; and, later in the war, during the trek back towards Borneo-it is probably fair to say that we would have faced a very uncertain future. At Milne Bay, the Japanese were defeated on land for the first time in generations. That was an important moment not just for Australia but also for America and for all the allied forces, both those in the Pacific and those in Europe. Australian troops had already earned respect throughout the world in various theatres of war. We do not have to dwell on them, but we remember such things as the Battle of Britain and the North African war, in which Australians distinguished themselves at places such as Tobruk. Of course those who supported the war effort were not just those who served in uniform; many served at home in semimilitary capacities, in, for instance, the Women’s Land Army and the Civil Construction Corps. Others MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (12.27 Pm)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, 15 August 1945 was a seminalvolunteered to serve in the Red Cross, CUSA and several other organisations. They played their part in making the war effort a significant one. At the end of World War II, Australia’s population stood at only seven million. Throughout the course of the war one million Australians saw some sort of war service. When you think about it, one in every seven Australians seeing some form of service is quite a remarkable effort. Thirty thousand of the brave Australian soldiers who served in World War II ended up as prisoners and some suffered unimaginable hardship in places like Changi and on the Burma railway and the Sandakan death march. Another 40,000 troops were killed in fighting. In the Pacific alone-and that is what really resonates with us as Australians-more than 9,000 Australians were killed, 8,000 were taken prisoner and 14,000 were wounded or injured. That was quite remarkable for a young nation. Believe it or not, I still have recollections of World War II. I was a very small child, but I can remember my father picking up troops hitchhiking along the road. I can remember the shopkeepers snipping the little tickets from the ration cards. I can remember the black cardboard that we used to have to put on our windows. I can remember some cars with various forms of carbon burners on the back to extend the life of petrol. I can remember the day the war ended. My parents and next-door neighbours partied right through the night and we walked home across the paddock between the two properties as the sun was coming up. During that party we went down to pick up someone from the movies-or ‘the pictures’ as they were called then-and people were walking around the streets painting ‘VP’ in whitewash on the windows. Those images come flooding back. It must have been a very trying time, especially in the period from late 1941-around the time of Pearl Harbour and what happened immediately afterwards down the Malay Peninsula-through to September 1942. That was the period of greatest peril. When you think about what happened in that period, Australia really was in danger. We thought the Battle of the Coral Sea was the invasion fleet coming for Australia-in fact, it was aimed at taking Port Moresby. Nevertheless, that was a great turning point, as was the Battle of Milne Bay, which I referred to earlier, and subsequently the Americans engaging the Japanese at Midway. Of course the war did not finish in September 1942. It was a long, relentless grind for the next three years. We saw some dreadful things happen: the sinking of the Centaur, the machine gunning of Australian nurses and, as I referred to before, things like the Sandakan death march. The first Australians who went into battle in the Pacific theatre, believe it or not, were the RAAF. They undertook bombing along the coast of Malaysia, particularly aimed at Japanese shipping. Their first contact was at a place called Kota Baru, along the Malay Peninsula. From then, right through until the campaigns in Borneo at the end of the war, Australians were continuously serving somewhere in the Pacific. It brings a whole flood of memories back to many people and it causes us to reflect on some of the values-the fortitude, the strength, the sacrifice and the bravery-of the troops and of citizens who contributed to the victory. Those emotions shine through when you have these presentations of medals. I was quite surprised at the depth of emotion that was still evident in the people who received those medals. A lot of them had many service medals and I thought that for many of them this would be just another medal but, no, it was a very moving return for many of them to 60 years ago. Those same people lived through the horror of losing family members and friends, particularly the war widows, and that was also a very moving MAIN COMMITTEE experience. Some people never quite got over that-as, I suspect, some people will never quite get over the horrors of the two Bali bombings we are commemorating today, because that is not someone dying of sickness or slowly fading away; that is sharp, brutal and indiscriminate. When the war did end, as I said, people were going around the streets putting ‘VP’ on the windows and waving flags. Then there were the tickertape parades, and I suppose the most iconic symbol of that time was the dancing man with the hat in the air in front of the tram in Sydney, which has now been captured, I noticed the other day, on the dollar coin. So, 60 years on, those sorts of images still resonate with us. As the euphoria faded away, Australians marked the end of the war with services and family gatherings celebrating peace and remembering the dead. There were some for whom the war did not end quite then. There was one group I will always admire. They were the guys who were brought in to disarm ordnance in about 1944, and they continued to do that right through until 1947. I used to get very angry that some of them did not get active service recognition. People told them: ‘You never faced the enemy. You were never in mortal danger.’ Good God! They had to take the plates off encrusted sea mines and dig out unstable landmines and the like, and with any trip, any slip of the spanner or the screwdriver, they could have been blown to kingdom come. So the war did not end for them or for many who went to Japan with the occupation forces. They fulfilled a role of what I suppose we could say was the start of the rebuilding of Japan and reconciliation with that country. I think the best way we can honour Australians who served in the Second World War is to remember why they had to fight for their country and to learn the harsh lessons of history. We must also remember that freedom carries a high price. It is not guaranteed and it must be vigilantly defended by each generation, sometimes in different ways. As we have celebrated this morning, and even in a bill that we discussed just a few minutes earlier, we have to be prepared to face new dangers in different modes. Had World War II ended differently we would not have the privileges we enjoy today. Now more than ever Australians must remember the service and sacrifice of previous generations and honour the contribution that many brave people made to this nation. electorate did not cease with the conclusion of services on Sunday, 14 August. The following Monday, in fact, I had the opportunity to present commemorative medals to a number of veterans. In a special ceremony attended by members of veterans’ families, and representatives indeed of the Ingleburn RSL, I had the opportunity to present medals to, spend time with and listen to the recollections of a number of World War II veterans-and listening to them from very much a different perspective. I was struck by the sheer determination that those who lived through the war expressed when they spoke about it. Deep within each of them. I could sense the fierce determination that was clearly so central to each of them making it through those hard times. Each of them had a story to tell-an act of bravery or of sacrifice-but they felt it was nothing more than anyone else was doing under those same situations. These are brave people who faced war up close and personal. The experience was nothing like the view through the remote camera lens that we tend to view conflict through today. Those who survived the war, and, tragically, those who did not, saw the war directly, sometimes with the enemy not more than a few metres in front of them. But each of them, in their MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Hayes (Werriwa) (12.40 Pm)
theText: by leave-The commemorations of VP Day in my own way, is quite humble about their contribution. While they might not think that their individual contributions were significant or anything particularly special, that is certainly not the case. While they might play down their contribution, I was more than pleased on that day to be in a position to make sure that it received fitting tribute. I was pleased to be able to share the day with them, to learn more of their experiences, to share in their stories and, quite frankly, to pay tribute to them. Much is made of the celebrations surrounding ANZAC Day each year, and rightly so, but it is also very important that all Australians had the opportunity to reflect on what is probably an equally significant day in Australia’s war history. It is worth recalling the words of the then Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, some 60 years ago, when he said: Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may we look forward to a perch which they have won for us ... Let us remember those whose thoughts, with proud sorrow, turn towards gallant loved ones who will not come back. Nothing can fully repay the debt we owe them, nor can history record in adequate terms their deeds ... The ceremonies that took place over that weekend in August, not just in my electorate at Ingleburn but throughout the country, were a fitting time to reflect on the achievements and sacrifices of Australians who served in the defence of our nation. The ceremonies not only were a means to mark an important anniversary of a country coming to age but were reflective of the ongoing debt of gratitude that today’s Australians have to Australians of that generation. The number of veterans may be dwindling, but I am sure that the memory of their contribution to our country will always be remembered-and I put that very clearly. Lest we forget. Sitting suspended from 12.45 pm to 4.01 pm Ms LIVERMORE (Capricornia) (4.01 pm)-Today in the Main Committee I would like to join with other members of the House in speaking on the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II. This is particularly an opportunity to commemorate Victory in the Pacific, which marked such an important point in Australia’s history, and one to which many brave and patriotic people from my electorate contributed. I wish particularly to refer to the battle honours of the second 42nd infantry battalion and, of course, to the men from all over Central Queensland who came together and formed this famous battalion. I could not speak about the 42nd without acknowledging the original 42nd Battalion, which was formed in 1915 and saw action during the First World War in France. During these actions the men of the first 42nd won 152 decorations for valour. It was on 23 September 1939 that Lieutenant Colonel JEG Martin received authority for the enlistment of recruits for a special expeditionary force. The area from which the troops were to be drawn was from Gladstone to Mackay in Central Queensland. Once formed, the 42nd Battalion was ordered into camp at Yeppoon on 4 October 1939. In September 1940 men aged 20, 22, 23 and 24 years went into camp, and the local newspapers announced that the Pacific was teetering on the brink of war. It was a Saturday afternoon when news of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor came through to the 42nd Battalion camp at Yeppoon, and most of the troops were on leave. To those who remained in camp over the weekend fell the huge job of transforming the camp to a war footing. For example, the rows of orderly tents had to be struck and moved into a dispersed pattern some distance apart and, where possible, under trees. Antiaircraft pits were MAIN COMMITTEE manned on picturesque Wreck Point and an observation group was stationed on North Keppel Island, just off the Central Queensland coast. That Christmas, one day’s leave was granted, and it was the last Christmas dinner most of the troops were to eat at home for many years. In March 1942 the battalion struck camp at Yeppoon and moved to join other battalions at Tiaro near Maryborough to form the 29th Brigade. Parents, wives, families and sweethearts were left behind and there was no way of knowing when or if they would be reunited. From all reports, though, spirits were still high amongst the men while they were stationed at Tiaro. As is the way of young men from Central Queensland, the 20 miles to Maryborough was not far enough to keep them away, even though there was no transport because leave to Maryborough was not permitted. Nonetheless, many a young lad was seen hitchhiking, and on one occasion 60 men sat astride one log on the back of a truck into town. It was on one of these visits that the so-called battle of Maryborough took place. Some well-known Central Queensland footballers were said to have featured in this incident and the story of the altercation between them and the locals at a downtown cafe was the main topic of conversation amongst the troops for some time. Later that year, however, the battalion moved to Townsville before they finally embarked on the Duntroon and Taroona in January 1943 and sailed to New Guinea. The men of Central Queensland were off to war. War is rightly denounced as a savage and loathsome exercise. Under its inescapable demands, men are plucked rudely from an ordered, sheltered life and thrust into unfamiliar and often horrific surroundings. However, this war did present some compensating features, for its harshness and crudity brought out those qualities of grit, comradeship and quiet heroism for which this World War II generation of Australians is so renowned. It is quite remarkable how few of these men resented the demands made of them when they finally returned to our country. Rather, there was a desire to perpetuate the comradeship and to honour the memories of fallen mates by returning to Australia and working to make it a strong and prosperous country-and one that we are lucky to live in today. I am very proud to continue today to give voice to those desires of the men from Central Queensland who gave so much. I wish here today to perpetuate their memories and the esprit de corps of the 42nd, which was to stand them in such good stead throughout their long and bloody New Guinea campaigns. The first battalion of the 29th Infantry Brigade to make contact with the enemy was the 42nd Battalion. This was on 13 August 1943, when patrols from B Company ventured into enemy territory on the slopes of Mount Tambu and were fired upon. They returned the fire and were very satisfied with being acknowledged as the first of the battalion to see action. But the battalion’s baptism of fire occurred a few days later, on 16 August. The fight started at 9.30 in the morning and lasted for an hour and a half. I want to recount that action to the House as it is recorded in the history of the 42nd Battalion. A patrol from B Company came under enemy fire. Hanging onto his stuttering Bren gun, George Eddlestone caused screams and wails of the most hideous kind to emerge from the enemy pits as he spluttered them with .303 bullets. Regardless of the risk he was running, Eddlestone kept his gun blazing. Bullets whined over his head and chewed up the ground on each side of him and behind, but still the Bren gun kept firing. Then the Bren fell silent. Eddlestone rolled over, shot through the heart. Enraged by the killing, huge Bill Green stood his whole six foot three inches and yelled at the top of his voice: ‘Come out and fight! Come out MAIN COMMITTEE or I’m coming in to get you.’ No-one expected Green to carry out his threat; not until they saw him streak up the ridge towards the perimeter. The enemy was all around him, but he did not care. He swore and yelled at them at the top of his voice and all the time his Owen gun was pouring out a stream of bullets. Eventually he fell to a burst of light machine-gun fire. No man died more bravely than Bill Green. His action was an inspiration to the whole battalion and he is rightly remembered as one man who knew no fear. The men from Central Queensland were now out there fighting and dying together. The men of the 42nd Battalion went on to serve their country and their battle honours include New Guinea, Milne Bay, Buna, Salamaua, Lea and Bougainville. It is not possible to list here the names of every individual from Central Queensland who served but I must place on record that they were everywhere-in the Air Force and the Navy and other Army unitsand of course there were women serving as well. And let us not forget those who stayed at home and worked, waited and worried. But it was the 42nd Battalion that was Central Queensland’s own and its story is so much a part of the story of Central Queensland. To continue the story, as the war drew to its bloody conclusion the men of the 42nd were still there. On 25 July 1945 an A Company security patrol ran into a booby trap and Privates MH Davids, MJ Timbs and EJ Smith were killed. Then, sadly, on 28 July Private SW Craker of B Company was killed just days before the Americans dropped the first atomic bomb on Hiroshima, thereby ending the Second World War. The battle record of the 42nd Battalion deserves to be acknowledged. No prisoners from the battalion were taken by the Japanese. The bodies of all the battalion’s dead were recovered. Every wounded man was picked up by his comrades and taken back to safety. The 42nd Battalion never lost a battle and never failed to carry out its task. Its battle casualties were severe and exceeded casualties from illness. Individual decorations were numerous-in fact too numerous to mention here. The last entry in the battalion diary was made by PrivateJ Rickarts on 29 October 1945, when he recorded ‘C in C’s parade held’. For the men of Central Queensland the war was over. Everyone looked forward to the postwar world: to home, old friends and old surroundings. Some were home quickly while others were further delayed. Most soldiers were unprepared for civilian life and therefore it often did not supply all the contentment that had been expected. Many found it was not so easy to settle back into the old routine-or rather what was now the new routine. For some it was the noise of a plane that would bring back visions of a crowded troop train. They again felt the weight of a rifle, experienced the smell of a jungle track or felt the sting of a mosquito bite. For each one the return was different, but gradually the men of the 42nd Battalion settled down to make Central Queensland what it is today. A meeting was held on 14 March 1946 and the second 42nd Battalion Association was formed. Elected to that committee some 60 years ago was the association’s current secretary, Malcolm Barker. On 25 April, ANZAC Day, every year for the past 60 years, the people of Central Queensland have gathered to stand and say thank you to the men of their own 42nd Battalion as they march together again, each man wearing with great pride his own 1939 to 1945 star, Pacific Star, 1939 to 1945 war medal and 1939 to 1945 Australian Service Medal. The men of the 42nd are indeed welcome home. outstandingly good speech. It was a great contribution to this parliament and a moving memoMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Hatton (Blaxland) (4.11 Pm)
theText: I congratulate the member for Capricornia on anrial to the members of the 42nd from Central Queensland. We should do this more often. The 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific has allowed us two things that we have not had in the time that I have been in the parliament. Firstly, it has allowed a memorial exercise on the actual day, or days surrounding that, to be held in our electorates, with the government funding that to the tune of $10,000. Secondly, government funding for each electorate is expanded by the resources of the local community. I want to thank the members of my community who took part in that and so well supported it. We had our memorial on 21 August, a week after most of the other celebrations, so as not to get in the way of the official ceremonies for our RSL people who were involved and also because ours was centred on Bankstown Airport. It was organised by the Australian Aviation Museum at Bankstown in conjunction with the local RSLs. What they were able to do was bring together World War II aircraft, buses, trucks and Army vehicles. Indeed the aircraft were not only Australian; there was also a Japanese Zero and an American Mustang there. It was a very special thing and that is why we had it a week later. Barry Thompson and the incredible volunteers at the Aviation Museum at Bankstown did an extraordinary job in bringing together people from all over the city of Bankstown and possibly even further. More than 1,500 people went through the Aviation Museum at Bankstown on the day. I was there throughout the day and I made the centrepiece of the day the presentation of medallions to some of those people in the electorate who were eligible to receive them. SomeI still have to present to people because they came in a number of different batches. In fact, I have started to initiate today the presentation of the remainder of the medallions. I think the most appropriate thing is to present them on 11 November in conjunction with the Bankstown RSL at their memorial for those who fell at Gallipoli and to do it in such a way, if they are agreeable, as to have a twinning of World WarI and World War II-a remembrance of those who fought and died in Europe and, in particular, in this case, in the Pacific to save Australia. There are those who argue now that there was never any intention whatsoever by the Japanese to invade Australia-that they had no plans, that they made no effort, that the Brisbane Line was unnecessary and that we just got a bit upset and shaken about because a few Japanese submarines came into Sydney Harbour and there was a bit of an attack on Darwin. They argue that those troops who were in Papua New Guinea, on both sides of the current border, and those troops who came down through the Kokoda Trail had no intention of ever moving into Australia-they were just going to park themselves in Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya and not do anything in relation to Australia at all. There are some significant historians who argue that-that there was no further intent. I think the only thing that would have stopped the Japanese during World War II from going any further was the fact that this is such a massive continent and they would have had the question of supply lines and also of what their major strategic objectives were. I have very little doubt, based on the historical evidence I have seen and based on what I have heard from my family and from the people who fought in that war, what they thought the intent of the Japanese was, because we took them on in the Pacific. The Prime Minister at the time, Mr Curtin, who was entirely against conscription during the First World War, not only saw the necessity, given Australia’s danger, to embrace the conscription of Australians during the Second World War-because the very survival of the naMAIN COMMITTEE tion depended on it-but also had to break the fundamental military ties with the United Kingdom because Mr Churchill, as Prime Minister, demanded that Australian troops go to the Middle East and fight, as we had fought in the Middle East, in France and in the Low Countries during the First World War, acting under imperial government orders. We went to war in World War II under imperial government orders. Australia did not take advantage of the fact that, as a result of the Balfour Declaration, Australia could have signed up to the Statute of Westminster in 1932 and would not have been at war automatically. What did the conservative governments at the time do? Absolutely nothing, and we were automatically at war in World War II as part of the British Empire, as we were automatically at war in World War I. Curtin made a fundamental decision. Faced with the extremity that Australia found itself in-faced with the collapse of Singapore, the British bastion in the Asia-Pacific area, and faced with what he found in the Battle of the Coral Sea where the Americans were brutally brought into the war by the attack on Pearl Harbor on 7 December 1941, after confronting the Japanese and their heavy march not only through the islands of Asia, the Pacific islands and the archipelagos of Asia but also through Burma and on the march through into India-Curtin made a fundamental decision that he would ensure that Australian troops were here to guard and protect Australia and to fight in the Pacific to ensure our national safety. This is the fundamental linchpin of all future Australian policy. It broke our link with the past, with Britain, and it fundamentally reordered Australian foreign policy on a completely new basis. It is the foundation of our relationship with the United States, forged in the Battle of the Coral Sea, and it is the foundation of modern Australian policy and of an independent Australian foreign policy directed by Australians to the protection of Australians. That was necessary if you look at the conjunction between World WarI and World War II. World War I, which is commemorated in Australia every year and is commemorated through ANZAC Day and also through November 11, is one part of the picture, but a far bigger picture for Australia is what happened during the Second World War and the impact that total war had on every Australian citizen at home and abroad. But that war was made during the First World War. The First World War saw the total destructions of the great empires of the past. It saw the breaking up of the Austro-Hungarian Empire; it saw the effective destruction of the British Empire, but people just did not realise it until World War II happened; and it saw a Japan become one of three countries on the rise politically, economically and militarily from 1870 on. Modern Germany was forged under Bismarck’s ‘blood and iron’ policy and its ability to train its people scientifically and to build its chemical, rubber and steel industries. Similarly, the United States, from 1870 on after the American Civil War, constructed an entirely new, modernised economy. Modern Japan was the third part of that. From 1870 to 1900, Emperor Meiji forged a new Japan by copying Western models, copying the United States and Germany. During the First World War, that new Japan was an ally of the United States, Great Britain and Australia. What went wrong? Why did we end up fighting a militaristic, fascist Japan during the Second World War? Essentially, not only did you have the complete destruction of those old empires but in their place in 1919 the Treaty of Versailles. Woodrow Wilson, an isolationist American President, joined with Clemenceau, Churchill and others to construct the world on the basis of small beginnings, of small, so-called democratic states-in some cases, real democratic states; in others, an attempt to be democratic states. One of the countries created in 1924 was IraqMAIN COMMITTEE and we know what problems we are in now when we get to the dissolution of one of the countries that was created after the fashion of the times. The creation of Czechoslovakia, the Sudetenland and myriad other small countries was an attempt to break up all of those empires and parcel them into small, democratic states but with a League of Nations that had no power to actually enforce peace within the world. What was seen in 1921 at the Washington Naval Conference was a determination that the United States and Britain, as the leading maritime powers in the world, should have a particular ratio that advantaged them vis-a-vis Japan. Japan got the message. They were told that, as an Asian power, they could not hope to come to pre-eminence in the Asia-Pacific region. They turned from allies of ours into a country that became dominated by militarists, who saw the future as a grab for power against the domination of the Pacific by the United States. They constructed their whole policy on speed of attack, which they demonstrated against the US in the attack on Pearl Harbor. Their approach in the Pacific was similar to the Blitzkrieg approach the Germans had developed-surprise, speed and devastating power. The Japanese moved very quickly through what they saw as the corrupted British, Dutch and French empires of the Asia-Pacific region and supplanted them extremely quickly. They then moved towards Australia with great haste and established themselves in Papua New Guinea and what is now Irian Jaya, then part of the Dutch empire. They were on a launching platform to either isolate Australia or, given what they did in Darwin-though they did not tell us during the war-make the first inroads to literally invading Australia. The men and women of Australia found themselves embroiled in a war that they did not ask for and found themselves automatically part of the British Empire effort again. Out of a population of four million in the First World War, 800,000 Australian soldiers signed up and 60,000 lost their lives. The population had increased to only about seven million, I think, by the time of the Second World War. We had more than a million men at arms during the war, pledged to Australia’s defence. It became a literal defence of Australia. Apart from the brilliant work done by the 8th Battalion in the siege of Tobruk and the important work done in Operation Torch later, Australia’s fundamental area of operation was the Asia-Pacific as part of a combined force under the leadership of General MacArthur which attempted to take back the islands and the countries of the previous Western European imperial powers in the AsiaPacific region. They did that, firstly, by holding the line and winning the Battle of the Coral Sea and the Battle of Midway and, secondly, through might and main and sheer hard, brutal work in New Guinea and Irian Jaya, confronting the Japanese soldiers and beating them back. They did it through the work of people such as Brett Collins in my electorate, who was stationed in Irian Jaya in a malaria infested, dengue fever infested area, where the 6,000 Australian soldiers who were sent there were told afterwards, when they had survived, that the expectation was that they would last a very short period of time because there were more than 100,000 Japanese soldiers bearing down on them. They did that through people like Doug McNally, who was in a position where he had to go from island to island intercepting Japanese code material, getting it down, breaking it, translating it and feeding the information back to Australian forces, including those forces at Bankstown airport who plotted our defence in the Pacific. Not one single Australian individual either at home or overseas could escape the effects of this total war. It was the conditioning of the Depression generation in Australia. It is right, fitting MAIN COMMITTEE and just that we salute all of them for what they went through to defend us in extremity. (Time expired) Ms GEORGE (Throsby) (4.26 pm)-I am pleased to be able to use this time to make some comments on the motion moved in the House by the Prime Minister, marking the 60 years since the Japanese surrender at the end of World War II. It was a most significant event in our nation’s history, for it was the first time that Australia came under threat of a direct attack. Out of a small population of some seven million people, almost one million Australians were mobilised in the war effort, both directly and indirectly. But it went beyond that: indeed the whole country was geared to supporting Australia’s effort. It was at that time that thousands of women for the first time entered the paid work force, often in heavy industry in the jobs that were left vacant by men who went to serve their nation overseas. Many women worked in a vast range of supportive and essential roles, such as those in the Women’s Land Army. The 60th anniversary of the end of the war provided the opportunity to recall our profound gratitude for the heroic achievements and sacrifices of those Australians who served in the defence forces and Merchant Navy during the war and all those who contributed on the civilian front. My generation is indeed a blessed one. We were spared the loss of life and suffering that touched so many families of our parents’ generation. We should not fail to recognise that 40,000 Australians lost their lives in that war and that 8,000 prisoners of war died in horrific circumstances in places like Changi and on the notorious Sandakan marches. These memories help in our resolve to ensure that the world lives in peace and that a conflict of this magnitude never occurs again. We recall the 55 million people around the world who lost their lives. So too do we recall the dropping of the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, graphically illustrating the destructive capacity of nuclear weapons and the dangers they pose for the survival of mankind. Much to our regret, our fears of the potential deadly force of nuclear weapons have more recently been reawakened. Many people do not realise how real the threat was to Australia. Lives were lost in Darwin, which felt the brunt of 60 or so air raids, as did other towns such as Broome in the north-west. Even Sydney Harbour was not spared, with the incursion of Japanese midget submarines and the loss of lives on the HMAS Kuttabul. What stood out for me in the commemoration in my electorate was the large number of young people who were very keen to participate and learn the lessons of history. It is much the same at every ANZAC Day service that I attend as well. In the time that I have available this afternoon I would like to take the opportunity to acknowledge the fine efforts of many people who worked on a voluntary basis in my electorate on that day to provide a fitting commemoration to mark the 60th anniversary of the end of the war. I begin by acknowledging the support of the federal government for a range of activities that we undertook and the financial assistance that was provided and the members of my staff who worked to ensure a very successful weekend of commemoration. The commemoration started on Saturday, 13 August, with the service march organised by the Port Kembla RSL subbranch. In particular, I thank Mr Ray Wetherall OAM, the president of that subbranch, and Angus Campbell, who took upon himself the coordination of the parade. And what a parade it was, with the Illawarra Pipe Band, the city brass band, the cadet units, the Light Horse troops and students from the local schools. MAIN COMMITTEE The main address on that day was delivered by Major General Brian Howard, who saw distinguished service in Vietnam. That evening the celebratory and commemorative atmosphere continued at a splendid dinner dance which involved many of our local community members. The next morning I was indeed honoured to present 65 commemorative medallions to World War II veterans, widows and widowers. Although it was disappointing that not all the medallions were processed in time for all the recipients to be granted their awards, those who were there on the morning were very pleased to have had their services acknowledged in a timely manner. On Monday, 15 August-VP Day-the morning began with the laying of wreaths at Shellharbour City. I participated along with the mayor and councillors of the Shellharbour local government area and representatives of all the local RSL subbranches. The Albion Park RSL subbranch organised an exhibition of ‘show and tell’ memorabilia from World War II. Local students were invited to Centenary Hall, and it was estimated that some 900 students passed through the exhibition on that day. It provided the ideal opportunity for surviving World War II service people and community members to meet and talk with our younger generation. I am sure that the interaction on that day helped lead to a better understanding of Australia’s role in the war. I place on the record my thanks to John Foran, President of Albion Park RSL, and Peter Ellis, Secretary of the Albion Park RSL, for this wonderful initiative. The commemorative events ended with a service on that day at the Warilla RSL subbranch. Their event involved representatives, again, of local schools and members of the Bass and Flinders Day Club. Each school was presented with a book for its library as a memento of the day. I thank President Keith Clemmett and Secretary Mary Clarke for their efforts in organising this event, which also displayed memorabilia from the era. You can see, Mr Deputy Speaker, from the acknowledgments I have made that indeed one of the highlights in the electorate for me as local federal member was the fact that we were able to garner that level of support, enthusiasm and activity to mark a very important day in our nation’s history. As I said earlier, I think what was really remarkable was the number of young people who were enthusiastically involved and who interacted with the older generation so that they, too, could appreciate the significance of those events in shaping our nation’s history and our identity. I also acknowledge the coverage that we received in the local media and, in particular, I want to conclude my comments by quoting some recollections of local veterans of VP Day, as reported in our local paper, the Illawarra Mercury. Former RAAF pilot Norman Gadsby, aged 82, recalled in his words that VP Day was indeed ‘worth a few sherbets’. He recalled: I was down in Melbourne when we got the news. We just went out and celebrated; it was an incredible day and a very long night. His wife, Joyce, was working at a building supplies store in Wollongong when word came through, and she recounted how people danced up and down the main street of Wollongong. Another recollection comes from George Shelton, aged 81. Steaming towards Japan on the British aircraft carrier HMS Indomitable was George-then a young man-who said that the jubilation he experienced, along with his mates, on the ship was tempered when he arrived in Hong Kong to be confronted with the horrors of Japanese prisoner of war camps. He said: MAIN COMMITTEE If you can imagine skeletons covered with skin-it was one of the worse days of my life. Noel Chapman, who served with the RAAF, reflected: These days have become important for the whole community, and in particular young people. That’s good because there’s not many of my mob left. In conclusion, I commend the Prime Minister for allowing members an opportunity to record their impressions, their thanks and their pleasure at the fact that their communities, through a wide range of activities across the nation, were able to come together and reflect on the significance of Australia’s involvement in the Second World War, the joy and some of the downsides of that experience, which really came to the fore on a weekend of great celebration and commemoration in the electorate of Throsby. in a personal and a national context. On ANZAC Day in 1949 I was almost five years old. At about half past four in the morning my mother woke me up. I think it was freezing cold. It was raining and it was windy. I very unwillingly went down with her to the train at the railway station at Largs North, where I lived, and caught the train to Adelaide. We walked to the Cross of Sacrifice and I attended my first dawn service, mesmerised-probably very confused-about what was going on. My mother, I could see, was very unhappy. I did not quite know how to deal with that. After the ceremony at the Cross of Sacrifice we walked down Pennington Terrace to North Terrace to the war memorial. In the war memorial in Adelaide you walk downstairs and all the names of the South Australians who died in the Great War and the Second World War are there. My mother went to the wall and rubbed her fingers along a series of names. She came to the last name, that of her brother, Reg Tuxford, who died in Corby in France in 1917. He was only a very young man. In fact, he lied to get into the Army. He was not allowed to join in South Australia, so he hitchhiked his way to Melbourne and did it from there. At that time my mother’s family had cousins-the Vincents and the Barnes. Not one of them who went to World WarI ever came home-not one. So a whole generation of relations of my mother were killed in World War I-all in France. My father’s family also served in France-every one of them came home alive and uninjured. In the Second World War my father’s family served in Tobruk, El Alamein and New Guinea, like many other families. Fortunately, they all came home, but some were very badly affected by their experiences in the Second World War. Each ANZAC Day went by and on one occasion, as I was sitting on the train, I remember a 10 shilling note being on the floor of the railway carriage. Enthusiastically-we were not very rich-I picked it up, gave it to mum and said, ‘Someone’s lost 10 shillings.’ She said, ‘You can have it.’ The next year it was a pound. The following year it was maybe another pound. When I was about 10, it was £10. That was half my parents’ wages. It took me all of that time to wake up to the fact that there was a guy who was always seated in the carriage who always lost money. It was perhaps his reward for my putting up with going to ANZAC Day. I continued to go to ANZAC Day and I continued to observe the characters of the generation who fought in the Second World War. There are three very special generations of Australians and South Australians. The first are the people who came to South Australia and founded the fledgling colony. They were brave, MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Sawford (Port Adelaide) (4.36 Pm)
theText: I would like to put my remarks this afternoongutsy people and we will never again see the like of those people in this country-or in the world. The second generation of very brave people were born in the period 1880 to 1910. Remember, at this time we thought the Russians were coming. To defend ourselves, we built forts along the coast of South Australia with great cannons. These people went through a worldwide depression in 1890 and the poverty right around the country in those days was appalling. In that context, there was a fellow called William Rooke Creswell, originally an Englishman, who came out to Australia to be the commander of the South Australian colonial ship the Protector, which fought in the Boxer Rebellion and served in World War I. I think it now forms a reef off the coast of Queensland, unfortunately. My Uncle Dave was the chief petty officer on the Protector-tough old cuss. William Rooke Creswell was a brilliant person. He became and is known as the father of the Royal Australian Navy. He became Sir William Rooke Creswell. Prior to 1910, all the Australian ships were part of the Commonwealth Naval Forces. He formed the Royal Australian Navy in 1910 and became a rear admiral. Interestingly, we have never adequately remembered him, and a lot of other people of that generation. Then comes the group who fought in World War II, the group we commemorate today. Remember they were children in the twenties, a time that was perhaps similar to today’s times when people lived the high life. Debt was huge. People were borrowing money on no collateral. Of course, the inevitable happened. When greed dominates economies, they go bust. So we had a depression and this generation lived through the Great Depression. In Adelaide thousands of people and their families were living in little shanties made of corrugated iron, cardboard and paper, living on the banks of the River Torrens. WhereI lived, people were living in the sandhills-not just one or two but hundreds of people. It was not a great time. Jobs were very difficult. In my grandparents’ house there were 14 men. Only two workedmy father and my grandfather-the other 12 were supported by that family. The bravest person who ever put on an Australian uniform was Thomas Currie Derrick, ‘Diver Derrick’, who grew up in Exmouth Road and Bucknall Road, Exeter, just around the corner from where I live. He could not get a job either. Like my father, he went up the River Murray in search of jobs: very poorly paid, with poor accommodation, but they got a feed. Diver Derrick came back and so did my father. My father was too old to serve in World War II and too ill, unfortunately, but Diver Derrick did. He served in El Alamein and got a DCM. He should have been awarded a VC, but he got a VC at Sattelberg in New Guinea. I will not go through his exploits but they are unbelievable. The Army tried to keep him out of the final days of World War II, but he wanted to be with his mates, and up in Borneo in the last days of World War II unfortunately he lost his life. We have not remembered him adequately in Port Adelaide either. There is a little street and a park, which I opened. He is regarded by all the military as the bravest person ever to put on an Australian uniform and we have not adequately remembered him. These people lived through tough times. Compare World War II with World War I-four years in the trenches blowing each other to smithereens, not gaining a yard. In World War II, Hitler was in Paris in six weeks. He was walking down the Champs Elysees six weeks after the invasion of Poland. It is almost amazing to say that they were in Paris in six weeks. Then, of course, there was the evacuation of the French and allied armies from Dunkirk. It was absolutely unbelievable, but it put the fear of God into everybody in the Western world. MAIN COMMITTEE We had the Battle of Britain, where many Australians served and lost their lives. There was El Alamein, Tobruk, Crete, Greece, the shock of Pearl Harbor, the bombing of Darwin, the bombing of Sydney, the fall of Singapore and the sinking of the Repulse and the Prince of Wales. My mother tells me that in the streets of Adelaide people were just petrified. Forget the historians who are trying to rewrite history; people believed that the invasion was only months away. The Philippines fell, MacArthur came to Australia and John Curtin made a plea to the United States of America. There was the Battle of the Coral Sea, the Battle of Midway and the Kokoda Trail, and here is a generation that survived all of that. They are now in their eighties and nineties. All of us have been to celebrations with these people. On the week before VP Day this year, I unveiled a plaque at the Port Adelaide Naval Association in memory of all the merchant seamen and Royal Australian Navy and Royal Navy personnel who lost their lives in World War II. On the 15th, I attended the Port Adelaide and Semaphore RSL to view a display of all the news clippings, souvenirs and memorabilia of World War II. It brings you back to earth. In many ways it is like going to a hospital and seeing someone fighting for their life. It puts your trivial worries, the worries that sometimes we blow out of proportion, into context. This is a generation that did other things too. After the war they participated in probably one of the greatest postwar reconstructions this country has ever seen. It happened under a Labor government. We have failed to replicate in any way that reconstruction of the late 1940s and early 1950s. But, more importantly, we also had a social contract on employment that the community fought for and both governments actually supported. In fact, it was a move around the world. I suppose it was the basis of the welfare state in the United Kingdom and of a different approach in the United States and Europe. It has not lasted long. There is a frightening and striking similarity between the signs in the 1920s of where a world got incredibly into debt and could not control it and the indicators of today, but that is for another day. In the next two weeks, like other members, I will be continuing to present Victory in the Pacific medallions to members of my community. I have been quite surprised: there have been about 1,900 in my electorate. Most people want them presented, and that has created a bit of a backlog for us. I think I have four presentations next week-one every morning! By the time you include friends and family it is a big function. Next week we will be based at the Port Adelaide and Semaphore RSL, assisted by Peter Davidson, the president, his committee and all his hard working members, who are putting on the lunch. AllI have to do is front up-I have the easy part-hand out the medallions, give a speech and thank everybody, and probably thank the younger versions of my parents’ generation for what they did. When I talked about the Port Adelaide Naval Association I forgot to thank Harley Doyle and his hard working executive for organising for me to unveil the plaque at the naval association. There is a bit of a sad touch to it all. One of my great supporters was Percy Lawrence, aged 86. On ANZAC Day and on Remembrance DayI used to have to share my time between Port Adelaide RSL and the Naval Association because of family connections. I could not be at both places at the same time, so when I could not be at the Naval Association, Gundi Lawrence, who was an old merchant navy person-he went into the Royal Australian Navy and served on the Wilcannia-would lay the wreath on my behalf. Unfortunately, Gundi recently passed away. He lived a rich life; he was a wonderful man. We remembered the matters of the victory MAIN COMMITTEE in the Pacific at his funeral, which was one almost bereft of grief. It was actually a celebration of this great man’s life. To Gundi and to Billie and the boys-Russell, Trevor, and Neville-I say thank you very much. (Time expired) Ms KING (Ballarat) (4.51 pm)-I was honoured and somewhat humbled to celebrate Victory in the Pacific Day in my electorate alongside local veterans. I would like to use this speech to personally thank all of the RSLs in my district for making this year’s VP Day celebrations both memorable and enjoyable. Commemorating 60 years since VP Day is a stark reminder that, without the sheer guts and determination shown by men and women of this country during World War II, I would not have the opportunity to stand in this place today. Growing up, I have always had an ardent interest in history and I know that 3 September 1939 was a day that the world will never forget. The battles fought during the Second World War defined the world in which we now live. It would be six years before Australia and the world were at peace. War with Japan was pivotal to the war effort, which brought the war to our very doorstep. World War II took Australians to virtually every corner of the world. Nearly one million men and women served in the armed services or merchant navy. From my own district, over 8,700 people who were born in Ballarat served in the Australian war effort-over 6,000 served in the Army; over 1,500 in the RAAF; 281 in the Royal Australian Navy; and nine in the merchant navy. We are not known for being surrounded by sea! Kim Beazley described the men and women who fought in the First and Second World Wars as ‘our toughest generation’ and he is absolutely right. Australians were involved in many conflicts, which took the lives of many of Australia’s finest citizens. They served on two fronts: at home and overseas. When we look at the history of the war and the efforts being made by Australians across all areas of battle, and when we reflect on the fact that Australia was one of the nations hit hardest by the Depression, it is an enormous tribute to the men and women of that generation that we rose out of that. During the war in the Pacific, we essentially defended and saved ourselves, and we emerged from that war a different nation and a very different people. There was no nation whose people were more mobilised than the Australian nation. In this country every man and woman was turned to by the government and those responsible for organising the war effort. In my electorate I have the fortune of having a fantastic group of veterans, who organised a number of events across the electorate to commemorate VP Day. I would like to thank in particular the Bacchus Marsh RSL which invited me to the Soldiers Memorial Hall on 15 August. Even the downpour of rain could not dampen the day. We moved the ceremony inside the hall, which was packed with veterans’ families, friends, local school students and community leaders. They were joined for the first time by the Ballan RSL. It was a fitting tribute for the day to see these two sub-branches there together. As part of the proceedings I presented local veterans with their World War II medallions. We then enjoyed an absolutely delightful afternoon tea. Ballarat Legacy held a special luncheon on the Friday before VP Day, and I hear that a very good time was had by all. The RAAF Association in Ballarat, in conjunction with ex-servicemen’s clubs, organised in Ballarat a VP service on 14 August. That coincided with the military history group’s re-enactment of several battles and they had a number of military personnel and military equipment out at the airfield. MAIN COMMITTEE The service at Ballarat was attended by the Ballarat, Buninyong, Sebastopol, Ballan and Creswick RSLs, alongside other ex-service organisations. Local veterans turned out in force, as did the Ballarat community, to recognise the sacrifices local veterans made for their community and their nation. However, the day was marked by a sombre note. Arthur Lealand, who was 81, collapsed during the commemorative service and, despite the best efforts of local bystanders and paramedics, he died shortly afterwards. I had met Arthur on a number of occasions and had spoken to him just before we marched off that morning. Arthur was absolutely ecstatic-there is no other word to describe his mood on that day. He was brandishing with pride the baton that was used to conduct the band at the signing by the Japanese of their surrender. Arthur was there, and he had arranged for the baton to be used at the opening of our Australian ex-POW memorial in Ballarat and for it to be specially used in Ballarat at the VP Day anniversary. He came up to the mayor, David Vendy, and me to show us the baton and his contribution was formally acknowledged at the service. Unfortunately, Arthur collapsed shortly after and, as one RSL member said to me, ‘When I heard the Last Post playing I looked over at Arthur and I hoped that somehow he heard it and he went to rest.’ I had the pleasure of meeting Arthur’s brother Colin the next day at the Daylesford RSL commemoration where he was the guest speaker. He told me that Arthur was a staunch Ballarat Legacy member and, by all accounts, a handy batsman. He also told me, somewhat wryly, that Arthur was the youngest of the three boys who had all made it home from the war, and that he had broken ranks somewhat by dying before the other two. Family and friends have said that Arthur could not have asked for a more fitting final salute than to be surrounded by mates during such a historic anniversary. Mr Lealand will be sorely missed, and I would like again to pass on my condolences to his family and pay my respects to the marvellous contribution Arthur made to this country and to our local community. It was at the Daylesford RSL ceremony where I had the pleasure and honour of meeting Arthur’s brother Colin and where Colin was the guest speaker. He gave a heartfelt and thoughtful speech. Again, as with all the VP Day commemorations in my electorate, it was great to see the whole community participating in the proceedings. The Clunes community also held a VP commemoration and lunch, and from all accounts it was a wonderful turnout involving all of the community, young and old alike. The VP Day commemorations held across my electorate were a fitting commemoration to all those who served in the Australian defence forces during our country’s hour of need, and much thanks is owed to all the hard work of the local RSLs who spent many hours organising the events. I, unfortunately, do not have the time to thank all of the people involved individually, and I do not want to leave anybody out, but I would simply record my thanks to all those involved. Your contribution and service is a credit to your RSLs, ex-service organisations and the local community. I, like other members here who are commemorating VP Day, have a number of medallion presentations to conduct. I will be doing my next one on Friday, and also several next week as we break from parliament. They are wonderful occasions and I think the medallion is a fitting way of recognising the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. I do have to say, though, that I have had a number of constituents talk to me about their disappointment about the criteria for the allocation of the VP medallion, particularly those families who have quite recently lost their World War II veteran, and they would like to be able to have the medallion in their MAIN COMMITTEE family. I have of course, and I am sure other members of parliament have done the same, written to the minister to ask for some reconsideration of that. In my own family’s case, the only boy remaining in my mum’s family died just recently and, as she is the sole survivor of the family, I know personally from her that it is something she would very much like to have in the family to be able to commemorate not only his war service but also her brother who died at the age of 21 in the Pacific. SoI think, whilst we are here commemorating VP Day, that perhaps there are some family members who are somewhat disappointed about not being able to have the medallion in their family and in their family history. I also, just very briefly, want to talk about an experience I had most recently. Whilst we are talking about Victory in the Pacific and the 60th anniversary of VP Day, this year is also the 90th anniversary of World WarI and of the ANZAC Cove landings. Two weeks ago I had the opportunity to visit Gallipoli for the first time with Mount Clear College students and teachers, and the Mayor of the City of Ballarat. The college has developed a sister city relationship with Gallipoli High School and, through the wonderful work of a teacher, Ian Simpkin, has developed a cultural exchange between the two schools. It was incredibly moving to be at the site and, I think, probably even more moving to be able to be there when there is not a large crowd; when the silence of the sea and the silence of the site itself really give you an indication of what an incredible place it was to land. One of the things I wanted to comment on is what has happened to the site in the course of the last 12 months. The teachers who were there with me have been to ANZAC Cove on four separate occasions. The roadworks that have been undertaken at that site, regardless of what spin the government wants to put on it, have irrevocably changed that site forever. To paraphrase, one of the teachers said to me: ‘I look out at this cove, and I have photos from 90 years ago and photos from last year. Over the course of those 90 years, the shape and the skyline of that cove had remained unchanged. The wonderful thing about being at that site is that when you look out you see almost exactly the same image that those boys landing 90 years ago saw.’ He was able to show that. He had those photos and he could see that. But when we were there two weeks ago he said: ‘I can no longer say that. These kids who I’m bringing here today will no longer see the same sight that those boys who landed at this site 90 years ago saw. It has changed.’ The thing that I was shocked by, it being my first visit there, was that, whilst the Turkish authorities have clearly sought to accommodate the requests of the Australian government to improve vehicle access, it is less clear just how much oversight, if any, the Australian government had over that process. The Turkish authorities have done what they were asked to do, but when you look at the site you see that great excavations have happened. There is still soil dumped on the cove itself and there has been no replanting at the site. I must say, there desperately needs to be some remedial action taken to get that site at least back into a condition where it does not look as though it is a building site. It is a war memorial. I understand there is a parliamentary delegation leaving to go to Turkey on the weekend, and I would encourage members of that cross-party delegation to look very closely at the site and make their own assessment. I understand that a Senate report is just about to be handed down and I would expect there are some critical comments in that as well. I would really encourage that parliamentary delegation to look very closely at the site, because there does need to be some attention paid to that and there needs to be some work done. I think that whilst we MAIN COMMITTEE are here commemorating the 60th anniversary of VP Day-an incredibly important event to commemorate-we have an equal responsibility to make sure that those war memorial sites are not just something we pay attention to when there are cameras on us and when there is a big crowd there on commemoration days. They are in our custody forever and we need to take great care when we do anything to those sites. Ms HALL (Shortland) (5.03 pm)-It gives me great pleasure to rise to speak on the motion before us today. The Second World War was, like all wars, a defining time in Australia’s history. It is really interesting to reflect on war and the part that it has played in Australia in bringing the nation together and forming our culture. After all, it was in 1915 at Gallipoli that all the newly federated Australian states came together as a proud nation. The Second World War also played a very significant role in the history of Australia, because it was the first time that Australians had to bunker down and fight on the ground to protect their own country. That was a very different way of looking at war. Previously, war had always been something that happened a long way away from Australia, but in the Second World War we were protecting our own shores. Every man, woman and child in the country joined the battle to save Australia. Australia was drawn into the war in the Pacific, in our own region, when we and the British colonies in Malaya and Singapore came under threat. It is also important to reflect on the fact that there were almost a million Australians-both men and women-who served in the Second World War. As well as the men and women who served in the actual conflict, there were many people who protected our home shores. There was the Women’s Land Army, established to encourage women to work in rural areas. Whilst the men were away fighting the war on foreign shores, the women were ensuring that those men had the food, the clothes and the equipment that they needed in that war. Like the other members of this parliament, I have been working closely with the veterans community. When we were organising our Victory in the Pacific celebrations, I had a committee that worked very closely with me. On that committee were representatives from all RSLs within the electorate: Peter Moss from the Doyalson-Wyee RSL, Joe Hayes from the Pelican Flats RSL, Roy McDougall from the Catherine Hill Bay RSL, Doug Wallace from the Swansea RSL sub-branch and Hughie Winter from the Belmont sub-branch. Peter Moore, the President of the Toukley sub-branch, also worked with me, particularly in the presentation of my first round of medallions. This committee helped me decide on the best way to allocate the $10,000 that the government provided for each member and their electorate. I would have to say that the choice was excellent. Money was given to Doyalson RSL for a very special commemorative function and to the combined Belmont-Swansea-Pelican RSL and the Catherine Hill Bay sub-branch for a similar sort of function. Out of the $10,000, money was allocated to purchase a Victory in the Pacific DVD for every school in the electorate. Those RSL sub-branches are going to help me distribute those at presentations within the electorate. So you can see just how important a role they played in the electorate and the celebrations and how I would be lost without the assistance that they give me-not only then but on all occasions. They are a very vibrant group, very caring about the welfare of all ex-servicemen within the electorate, and they are a group that provides support to them and their families at all times. On this occasion, they provided support and assistance to me. MAIN COMMITTEE When I was looking at the celebrations, how they affected people and what people thought when they heard that victory had been declared and that the war was over, I spoke to my mother. She said that she was standing in the kitchen preparing her breakfast. It was 7.45 in the morning. Next thing she knew, a friend burst in the back door and said, ‘The war’s over! The war’s over!’ Within about half an hour, the whole house was filled with friends and the celebration began. SinceI spoke to her, I have also spoken to many of the people who have attended the celebrations that I held throughout the electorate. One woman worked in the accounts department in a firm in Sydney. You may remember those machines that punch cards. They had been saving all of the little circles that had been punched out of the cards, and when they heard that the war was over they gathered these bags of confetti, went to the windows and threw the confetti out. And so the celebration began. Another person was in hospital in Singapore, and there was someone on a ship and a woman driving in a car-she and her husband were together. They were just overcome by the joy of the occasion. This is something that we probably find a little bit difficult to understand, because this had followed the Depression-as other speakers have said-where there had been extreme deprivation. It was a time when people in Australia had done it hard and battled in a way that I have never had to battle and that my children have never had to battle. I know that in the Depression my grandfather bred chooks. Those chooks were used to sustain his family. They grew things to eat in the garden, whereas these days most people just walk to the supermarket and buy those things.
