So it was a totally different time-a time when Australians had been poverty stricken. It was a time that followed the Great Depression, but even given that hardship Australians had the resilience to fight and work to save our nation. It is also important to note that the Second World War was a time of massive industrialisation. As I said before, it was quite often the women who moved in. We produced our own equipment and food. We fought the war and we fed and equipped the people who fought in it. My father-in-law did not fight in the war; he was required to stay at home. He was a radiographer and his job was to X-ray all the bombs to make sure that everything was properly manufactured. So there were so many different ways that people contributed to the war effort. As I mentioned, Australian women ran Australian industries. It was a time of great change for the women of Australia. They had to work in munitions factories while the men were on the Kokoda Trail. It is important to mention here that Kokoda is considered Australia’s most significant campaign of the Second World War. It was there that Australians halted the Japanese advance into Australia. It was a defining moment in Australia’s nationalism-as was the battle in Darwin-when the nation was saved from invasion. It was defining because Australia was under threat and we fought and saved our nation. At a local level, each year we have a commemorative service at Norah Head on the Central Coast. We are commemorating the effort that the Merchant Navy made to Australia’s war effort. On that day we remember the many people who lost their lives at sea. We particularly remember the sinking of the Nimbin and the Iron Chieftain just off the coast at Norah Head. It is a very poignant ceremony each year, and it is interesting that the entire coast of New South Wales-I say New South Wales because that is the area I am familiar with-is littered with ships that were sunk during the Second World War. We do not realise just how close to home the war was. MAIN COMMITTEE My mother tells me that she was out on Sydney Harbour on the day the Japanese submarines pulled up. She had had to travel from Manly to Sydney. She has shared with me the feelings that existed at that time. Another friend, Lachy Watkins, helps me out a lot when it comes to veterans ceremonies. When I am down here, he invariably represents me. Except for last year when he was at Gallipoli, which was a very special time for him, he has accompanied me on every ANZAC Day ceremony I have attended whilst I have been in the parliament. He was in the 2nd/33rd Infantry Battalion and served in New Guinea, Moratai and Borneo. He was at the bottom of Shaggy Ridge. He still wakes in a sweat at night, shaking from the memories of that war. He says the memories are always with him. He says that, no matter what, he cannot forget what happened there; it is forever with him. The terrain in New Guinea was formidable and difficult and combat was often in torrential rain. There were more deaths from tropical disease than from combat fatalities. One description I read of the area described it as one of ‘swift-flowing mountain streams, dense, dank rainforests and almost vertical mountainsides’. Our troops who were there suffered from extreme sleep deprivation and inadequate shelter, food and medical supplies. They battled constant wetness, knee deep in mud, and the tortuous terrain of the Owen Stanley Range. They had to contend with the worse tropical diseases. They were ordinary, everyday Australians. They were Australians from my region who worked in the mines. They were Australians who, after the Depression, were battling to care for their families. Above all, they joined together as proud Australians to defend our coastline. We as Australians should be very proud of them. We as Australians are very proud of them-not only those who fought in New Guinea but also those who fought Hitler in Europe. Their role and contribution was enormous. They were involved in every aspect of the war in Europe. As a nation, we are very proud of them. We are also very proud of those who fought the battle at home-the women who were involved in providing the equipment, food and munitions that our soldiers needed. Australia salutes and thanks all those who fought for Australia in the Second World War. Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney) (5.18 pm)-World War II ended on 15 August 1945. We have recently had the opportunity to express our gratitude to those who served in the Second World War, to honour those who are still with us and to commemorate those who fell. In announcing the end of the war against Japan on 15 August 1945, Prime Minister Chifley said: Fellow citizens, the war is over. The Japanese government has accepted the terms of surrender imposed by the allied nations and hostilities will now cease. The reply by the Japanese government to the note sent by Britain, the United Nations, the USSR and China has been received and accepted by the allied nations. At this moment let us offer thanks to God. Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may look forward to a peace which they have won for us. We can only imagine how much relief and how much joy was in the hearts of people hearing the words that war was now over, yet how much sadness there must have been for the people that they had lost and the sacrifices that they had made. Some one million Australians served during World War II and almost 40,000 of them were killed. Many more people were injured during the war and 30,000 were taken prisoner. For every one of those who did not come back, there is a family who still grieves. For those who did come back, changed by war, there was a lifetime of readjusting. I think we should also remember that, although Australians suffered during this war, the peoples of every nation suffered. That is the problem with war. MAIN COMMITTEE Less than a week before the cease-fire, many Japanese people were killed in the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki when those new and deadly bombs were dropped. I think it is worth remembering that those people too-women, children and noncombatants-died in a terrible way at a terrible time in our international history. The war ended and soldiers returning had all sorts of difficulties in readjusting to their civilian lives. Many of the women who had taken up the burden of working in the factories and on the farms had enjoyed their new-found competence and freedom, and suddenly they were expected to drop all their new skills and return to the home to raise families. They certainly loved their families, but the war had shown them that it was possible to do more-to do work that benefited the community and brought income into the family as well as raising their children. Just as many of the soldiers had difficulty readjusting to their lives as civilians, I think many women had difficulty in adjusting to the idealised life that was set out for the 1950s housewife. Recently in my electorate we had a ceremony to honour those who served Australia and the allied nations. We had a morning tea on Friday, 12 August at the Australian National Maritime Museum. There we unveiled a commemorative plaque and presented special medallions, commemorating the end of the Second World War in the Pacific, to World War II veterans, their widows and widowers. There were 874 eligible recipients in the electorate of Sydney, and we were able to invite all of those people to the morning tea at the Maritime Museum because of the extraordinary generosity of the Australian National Maritime Museum. I take this opportunity to thank in particular the Director of the Maritime Museum, Mary-Louise Williams, and the Assistant Director, Michael Crayford, who did an excellent job as Master of Ceremonies on the day, and Inger Sheil, who did the bulk of the organising of this day. We thank all of the staff at the museum who helped and supported this event not just for their work on the day but also for their work during the lead-up to the day. We now have a wonderful commemorative plaque on the wall of the National Maritime Museum, facing Sydney Harbour, that thousands of tourists pass every day and that thousands of schoolchildren can see every week. Veterans of World War II can see it at any time and know that Australia honours their work and honours their sacrifice. I want to particularly acknowledge the very good work of a number of the local RSL clubs in putting on this function. James Park, who is the Honorary Secretary of the Balmain-Rozelle RSL Club, and Aub Silcock from Redfern RSL were absolutely tireless in their efforts to make this event the wonderful success that it was. All credit should go to James and Aub for their hard work. But their work does not stop at this one event: each of them is organising or has organised further events in their local sub-branch areas to remind the community, particularly our young people, of the importance of this anniversary of victory in the Pacific. I would also like to thank Father John Knight, the parish priest of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Waterloo, who offered prayers on the day and our friend from the Salvation Army who also offered prayers on the day. Bill Orton, the President of the Balmain-Rozelle RSL Club, made a wonderful contribution. We thank State Transit for providing buses to transport all our veterans and schoolchildren. Our photographer, as always, was the wonderful Izzy Perko. He has sent a photograph of every veteran or every veteran’s widow or widower receiving a medal to them. I know that those photographs have been greatly appreciated. MAIN COMMITTEE Councillors Tony Pooley, Marcelle Hoff and Shayne Mallard attended from the City of Sydney Council. Our very special guest was Mr Tom Uren, a former minister in the Whitlam government. Tom enlisted in the Royal Australian Artillery in 1939 and later served as a bombardier with the 2nd/1st Heavy Battery in Timor. From 1942 to 1945, he was a Japanese prisoner of war in Timor, Java and Singapore, on the Burma-Siam railway and in Japan. Tom remembers the dropping of the bombs on Nagasaki and Hiroshima; he remembers seeing the mushroom clouds. Of course those years as a soldier and, more particularly, as a prisoner of war were terrible years not only for Tom but also for the men that he was locked up with. But those years built in Tom a spirit of forgiveness, compassion and generosity that I think he would agree were in many ways the making of him as a man. We were very lucky to have Tom with us on the day not only to remind us of his experiences but also to remind us that war is never to be glorified and that these opportunities are not opportunities to glorify war but to honour the sacrifice of the people who went to fight fascicm. The people who received medals on the day were Mr Frank Balbi of Rosebery, Mr Francis Breen of Balmain, Mr Harry Brindle of Camperdown, Mrs Lydia Bushell of Glebe, Mr Dusan Davidovic of Chippendale, Mrs Ethel Driscoll of Beaconsfield, Mr Alan Duncan of Balmain, Mr Donald Gale of Sydney, Mrs Sonia Gidley-King of Woolloomooloo, Mr Denis Gray of Millers Point, Mrs Elaine Hickey of Redfern, Mrs Isabella Jones of Potts Point, Mr Thomas rick Morriss of Glebe, Mr Iukhym Sapozhnikov of Waterloo, Mr Roland Schilling of Glebe, Mr Harry Slarke of Centennial Park, Mrs Maria Texeira of Waterloo, Mrs Sylvia Wardell of Balmain, Mrs Alice Weeks of Waterloo, Mr Ken Buckley of Sydney, Mr Efim Solovei of Surry Hills, Mr Burt Mulford of Redfern and Mr James Gray of Glebe. We also had a medal for Mr Bill Orton and we honoured Mr James Park and also Mr Aub Silcock. This may be the last chance that veterans of Victory in the Pacific have to gather in great numbers to have their particular contribution honoured. SoI wish to say to every one of the people on the list I have just read out and to every one of the over 800 people who are eligible for this honour in the electorate of Sydney: we thank you for your sacrifice and we acknowledge your hard work. We know that the number of young people who attend ANZAC Day services across the country continues to grow. Again, I do not believe it is because these young people honour war. I think it is because they honour sacrifice. Just as we remember those who fought for us, when I looked into the eyes of the veterans to whom I was presenting medals I knew that they were remembering their mates who fell. pause and record its thanks, gratitude and appreciation for the sacrifice of a generation of Australians who, during World War II, saved Australia. There is a simple truth in all of this: that generation and their deeds did in fact save Australia from tyranny. They established the basis for what has been 60 years of relative peace and prosperity, and without their great deeds that would not have been possible. A while ago this parliament discussed a similar motion in respect of victory in Europe, and it was appropriate that we paused then to acknowledge the contribution in that theatre of war. As with the European campaign, Australian forces distinguished themselves in the AsiaPacific region. It is probably the case that the first defeat suffered by the Nazi war machine in MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Marshall Of Alexandria, Mrs Juanita Minter Of Balmain, Mr Rex Minter Of Balmain, Mr Pat
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Bevis (Brisbane) (5.30 Pm)
theText: This is an important occasion for the parliament toEurope occurred at Tobruk, which was largely held by Australians-indeed, the first defeat for Rommel was with forces commanded by an Australian officer. The same can be said in the Pacific theatre of war. The Japanese war machine had effectively conquered all through Asia-through Korea, China, Indochina and Malaya, and had taken what was then regarded as the invincible stronghold of Singapore. It was not until August 1942, when they sought to take Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, that the Japanese suffered their first defeat on land. That was at the hands of Australian troops, most of whom were citizen soldiers. They were not career soldiers. They were part-time soldiers who had taken up the call to defend their country and their families. They had gone to New Guinea to resist the expected invasion, which came on 25 August. In extremely fierce fighting over some 10 days they repelled the Japanese attack on Milne Bay, and in so doing inflicted the first defeat on the Japanese army. At the same time, and over the period of that battle, Australians were engaged in another very bloody encounter, on the Kokoda Trail. I think few Australians grow up without knowing the story of the Kokoda Trail and the great sacrifices by Australians and by Papua New Guinea citizens on the Kokoda Trail. I think we should acknowledge the contribution of those Papua New Guinea citizens, the people who lovingly became known as the ‘fuzzy wuzzy angels’ and without whom many more Australian lives would have been lost. We often see photos of Australian wounded being helped down treacherous mountainsides in terrible conditions by the fuzzy wuzzy angels. What is not as widely known is that many of them served in their own Papua New Guinea battalions and took up arms and fought alongside the Australians. Also not often recognised is that, for most of the war in the Pacific, General MacArthur, the Supreme Allied Commander in the Pacific, had more Australians under his command than Americans. It was not until 1944 that MacArthur had more Americans under his charge than Australians. The brunt of the land battle in the Pacific was borne by Australian men and women. To their great credit, they performed with enormous valour and courage. The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, in his contribution at the start of this debate, referred to the writings of an American historian in a book titled Touched With Fire. I want to repeat that reference because it rang a chord with me and a number of others with whom I have spoken. This was an American’s view of Australians involved in Papua New Guinea during those days. The American observed: The ingenuity required on the frontier, which Australians call the ‘convict mentality’, was very real. There was also a genuine ruggedness to the national character. Physical courage was highly prized. A broken nose was easy enough to come by in pre-war Australia ... It is, I think, safe to say that somewhere along the line the ‘Protestant work ethic’ lost some of its intensity in Australia. An Australian infantry man who served at Milne Bay told me they were glad to hear of the Japanese attack because that freed them from an ugly road building detail in the mud. He concluded: Soldiers who would rather fight crack Japanese assault troops than build roads win wars. And indeed they did. I think it is a very insightful observation of those rugged Aussies by an American historian. I think we should also pay tribute to the other Australians who were involved-not necessarily in such a high-profile way. Whilst the Army was heavily engaged in the war in the PaMAIN COMMITTEE cific-at Kokoda and Milne Bay and on the islands of the South Pacific-it was supported by Royal Australian Navy and Air Force personnel. They fulfilled not just the normal combat roles but a wide range of other roles, including strategic support and intelligence gathering. Some of those intelligence-gathering activities were every bit as treacherous and dangerous as the front-line combat activities. Australians who had the role of spotter were stationed with their radios on small uninhabited islands across the Pacific, and their observations of the movements of Japanese navy and aircraft were essential in providing the intelligence that allowed the allied forces to do so well in the major battles of the Coral Sea and Midway. Without the intelligence that they were able to provide at great risk to themselves, events may well have turned out differently. I suppose their role is more often recognised, to the extent that it is, by virtue of one particular incident, where an Australian noticed that an American patrol boat had been sliced up in the night. It just happened to be commanded by John Kennedy, who later became President. It was an Australian spotter who was able to relay the information that rescued JFK and the survivors of his crew. The people in the Navy and the Air Force who provided that support and those in the Air Force who engaged in the bitter air battles in the Pacific deserve great commendation as well. Certainly in the early part of the war they often engaged in battles with inferior equipment but never without great commitment to their country. I also want to acknowledge the people who were back home during that period. Some of those were in uniform and eager to go to war but never did. There was an Australian armoured corps unit, the name of which I forget at the moment. They were equipped with Matilda tanks and it was intended for them to go abroad on two occasions but they were never able to. I have met a number of people who were in that unit, and they certainly would have matched the courage of other Australian troops who were involved in that theatre. There are also the people who protected Darwin and Northern Australia from the attacks that occurred on land from the bombings of the Japanese air force. I also want to acknowledge the role that women played during that period, including the Women’s Land Army, which was absolutely critical in ensuring that the needs of the nation continued to be met while literally millions of its people-its men-who had held down jobs were at war. Mr Price interjectingthe role that women played in all walks of life in industry. This enabled the planes to be built, the weapons to be made and the vehicles to be constructed. None of that would have been possible without the role of women. There is no doubt that the women who were involved in those many facets of activity during World War II, whether it was formally as part of the Women’s Land Army or in other roles in industry, played an essential part. I also want to include a comment about the role of Indigenous Australians in the Australian Defence Force. They receive, I have to say, far too little recognition for their contribution. There were outstanding examples of Aboriginal Australians making such a contribution. And we have to remember that at that time they had no right to vote or even to be counted as human beings in the census. They were not regarded by the government of the day and the nation as a whole as people to be counted in a census. They were not, in most parts of Australia, paid the same wage in civilian employment as the white person working beside them. But MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Bevis
theText: As I am correctly reminded by my friend the member for Chifley, there wasthey were committed Australians and many Aborigines served in the Australian Defence Forces-in all services, but particularly in the Army and the Air Force. I think it is a great tragedy, frankly, that it took until two decades after the war for them to receive the same basic rights as all other people, following the referendum in the mid-1960s. They should be remembered. Aboriginal Australians who fought during that period did so with great valour, and I hope that one day their story will be receive more publicity than it has had until now. Finally, I want to acknowledge the people in my own electorate who have participated in the commemorative celebrations that have been held and who will participate in the celebrations that are yet to be held. This SaturdayI will have the great honour and pleasure of attending a film evening with about 150 to 200 of my constituents. There will be some World War II newsreels, a large number of old diggers and their families, and the opportunity to present some awards to some of those assembled there. It is going to be a great evening. These occasions are important and, as the member for Sydney pointed out, they are important not because anyone wants to glorify war-the tragedies and the harm that come from that are all too obvious when we turn on our television sets every night. But it is more than appropriate that we thank those people for their sacrifice and acknowledge their contribution. Occasions like this are important for doing that. I want to especially thank the many people at the Gaythorne RSL in my electorate who have given their time-not just on occasions like this but on every day of the year-to support our veterans, as have the members of the Ashgrove RSL and the Bardon RSL. They do a fine job and we all owe them a debt of thanks for their support of a generation that was special. In conclusion, I think this generation deserve greater thanks and credit than any other I can contemplate-and not just because of the deeds performed during World War II. This was a generation that grew up as children during the Great Depression. As young people they did not enjoy any of the normal worldly benefits that we might have enjoyed when we grew up or that our children do. They grew up and, as young adults, went into a war. After having gone through a depression, they moved as young adults into a war over many years to defend our nation. They then came back and put their shoulders to the wheel and helped build one of the most prosperous countries on the planet. That is a great testament. I think any one of those things makes a generation stand out, but that generation endured all three and did so with great fortitude, great pride and a great outcome. I think it is a wonderful testament to them and it is appropriate that we should acknowledge them. friend the honourable member for Brisbane and shadow minister for homeland security. Certainly, I totally endorse all of his contribution. I begin my contribution with the remarks I made in my electorate and with which the Leader of the Opposition concluded his contribution to this debate. They were the words of Ben Chifley, the then Prime Minister, a month after Curtin died. On 15 August he said: Fellow citizens, the war is over ... Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may look forward to a peace which they have won for us. Let us remember those whose thoughts, with proud sorrow, turn towards gallant loved ones who will not come back ... Nothing can fully repay the debt we owe them, nor can history record in adequate terms their deeds from the black days that followed September 1939, and December 1941, until this moment. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Price (Chifley) (5.44 Pm)
theText: I somewhat reluctantly follow the contribution of myI cannot say that I have experienced war; in fact, I am a baby boomer born in the year that peace was declared. I think we forget what Australia was like in those days. Out of a population of six million, half a million people were under arms. We paid as we went as far as the war was concerned. Today we are a population of 20 million. We are not at war and our armed services comprise something like 50,000 people. As the honourable member for Brisbane pointed out, so many people contributed and so many received inadequate recognition for their efforts. I am pleased that he raised the issue of those in our Indigenous community who served and have been very much ignored. I wish to speak of the contribution of Australia’s women. Australia, under its total mobilisation then in place, could not have kept wartime industry and the civilian components that were operating going without the contribution of women. When I say ‘the contribution of women’, they actually did jobs that they had never done before. They did jobs that were seen as jobs for men. They worked in munitions factories and on tanks and aircraft. Again, the honourable member for Brisbane has outlined that. I know enough to understand that there is nothing nice or attractive about war. I think that the older one gets the more one wants to very much avoid war. It is never the old who glory in war, but it is the old who send the young men and women of a nation to war. We had a wonderful ceremony in Chifley, the details of which I would like to place on the public record, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick. A mutual friend of ours and former Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca, initiated an Australia Remembers service. I have to say that I have always counted myself a good friend of Con Sciacca. I put on the public record that he did not get to open the memorial gardens in the electorate of Chifley, much to my bitter disappointment. The gardens were a combined effort of the Rooty Hill and St Mary’s RSL sub-branches. Those memorial gardens continue today. I am fond of saying that council does not have flowers west of Alpha Park in Blacktown, but we have roses in the memorial gardens. They are a beautiful thing and both RSLs contribute many man-hours and hard work to keep them in pristine condition. Kevin Hall, the president of the Rooty Hill RSL sub-branch, and Leanne Taylor, the president of the St Mary’s RSL sub-branch-who unfortunately could not join us on the daywere the two chief officials. It was just a wonderful ceremony. I got an unexpected but special reward, which was the privilege of unveiling a plaque in the memorial gardens. I was very touched. For me to unveil that plaque in front of people who had served during the war, been widowed during that war or served in subsequent wars under the Australian flag was a very moving thing. I did not get a lot of notice on the speech, but nevertheless I hope I did them proud. But more than the remarks of the officials, or of the chaplain, I might say-I mean no disrespect-what gave real significance to the ceremony was the participation in the ceremony of all the students from the primary schools in Mount Druitt and the surrounding suburbs. It was just wonderful. Please forgive me if I mention the schools, but I am indebted to the teachers and more so to the students. I know it affected me, and those veterans appreciated it heapsthe students made it even more meaningful for them. The schools included Rooty Hill Public School, St Marys South Public School, St Marys North Public School, Bidwill Public School, Shalvey Public School, Hebersham Public School, Glendenning Public School, Colyton Public School, Dawson Public School, Lethbridge Park Public School, Willmott Public School, MAIN COMMITTEE Minchinbury Public School, Plumpton Public School, Mount Druitt Public School, St Marys Public School, Eastern Creek Public School, Blackett Public School, Tregear Public School, Emerton Public School, Hassall Grove Public School and Noumea Public School. Thanks to those students. Once upon a time in this country we had to fight hard to perpetuate ANZAC Day, which primarily commemorates World War I, but it is these students’ understanding and sense of the sacrifice and what it was like, not any contribution here today-notwithstanding, I am sure, many fine contributions-which will perpetuate our memories and our gratitude for all those who served and all those who contributed, many of whom lost their lives. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, I know that you have a relative who fought in World War I. I hope that in the future we never see a war of this dimension, although the nature and character of war seems to have changed quite dramatically. We often talk at different services about how much those actions contributed to peace, but I often wonder whether we honour the people involved, particularly those who lost their lives, by fighting for peace just that little bit harder. As we have turned the century and as we have turned the millennium, it has not been a peaceful planet, I have to say. It is not a peaceful planet in the way I think we would all have hoped that it would be. If we want to honour veterans and honour so many people other than veterans and their families who contributed to our success in World War II, we, particularly as legislators in this place, owe it to them to work that little bit harder for peace. Ms HOARE (Charlton) (5.53 pm)-I am very pleased to join my colleagues on both sides of the House as we pause to remember the men and women who sacrificed their lives in a time of war, particularly on this occasion of the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day. Like many of my colleagues, I have had the honour and the privilege of presenting commemorative medallions. On Saturday, 13 AugustI was able to present medallions to 70 local World War II veterans and widows at the Toronto RSL Memorial Club. On Tuesday next week I will be continuing that presentation, with a medallion presentation to veterans and widows at the Boolaroo Speers Point RSL Memorial Club. We have all mentioned the commemorative activities that have taken place in our electorates to commemorate the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. The Toronto RSL subbranch began planning their commemorations more than 12 months ago, back in September 2004, because they knew that this would be a significant occasion and they were going to have the biggest and the best regional commemoration to celebrate the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. On Sunday, 14 August, I was honoured and privileged to participate in the commemoration ceremony. It was the largest in regional New South Wales and local school students performed extremely well. The sub-branch organising committee had a strong commitment, as the member for Chifley was just saying, that young people in our region should lead the commemoration honouring veterans and widows because young people really are going to make the difference, to make sure that we live in a peaceful world in years to come. On Monday, 15 August, the organising committee held a special luncheon at the Toronto RSL Memorial Club to honour World War II veterans and widows and to commemorate the end of World War II. It would be remiss of me not to mention a lot of the people involved. There were the 12 months of organisation, the medallion presentation on the Saturday and the students had a march down the Boulevard, the main street of Toronto, around to the cenotaph. Only people MAIN COMMITTEE honouring the veterans marched; the veterans and widows who were being honoured stood along the roadside and then joined us at the cenotaph for a program run entirely by school students from Lake Macquarie Christian College at Fassifern, Toronto High School, St Paul’s High School at Booragul and Blackalls Park Public School choir. There was not an adult voice to be heard throughout the whole ceremony. The weekend commemoration was organised by the organising committee of the Toronto RSL sub-branch. I honour them here today: they did a fantastic job. The chair of the committee was Henry Miller. The school liaison person was Cec Donaldson OAM, who is a longtime stalwart and supporter of our local community. The patron of the Toronto sub-branch is Air Vice Marshal Jack Cornish (retired) AO, CBE, LVO, AFC. The publicity officer was Peter Stephenson. The secretary of the organising committee was John Handley. The assistant secretary and all-round gofer was Ron Richardson. The treasurer was John Renfrew. Other committee members were Brian Field and Gordon Gardiner. They should be very proud of the way the activities went and of the successful events over the whole weekend. The main commemoration happened on the Sunday. At the service we had the honour of the RAAF Air Command Band from Richmond and also the Australian Army Reserve Band from Newcastle. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, I do not think you have had the opportunity to visit Toronto on the shores of Lake Macquarie; you should come one day. During the Sunday afternoon, we all adjourned to the park down on the foreshore and the RAAF band went into swing in the rotunda there. Everyone enjoyed a wonderful sunny afternoon down by the lake following the commemorations. There was also a flyover that had been arranged by the organising committee. It was vintage planes that were owned, operated and provided by Cole Paye and Phil Unicomb. It was a flyover comprising Kittyhawk, Wirraway and Trojan planes. Then at 1 pm on the Sunday we had a jet flyover that came from Williamtown RAAF base. For those of us who were not ready for it, it came as a bit of a shock. We do not usually have RAAF jets flying over Lake Macquarie. The commemorations also included a publication. It was suggested by the organising committee that a publication be produced by high school students. It was, and it is called Sacred Records: Stories from World War II. It was compiled and edited by children from Toronto High School. These students did this under the supervision of their teacher, Mrs Beverley Richardson. They are year 7 independent learner students at Toronto High School and this publication is a great credit to them. It is going to serve as a memory and a way to continue honouring World War II veterans and widows. A lot of stories in this publication came from these students interviewing members of their own families. As I said, Cec Donaldson OAM is a local identity and the first interview was with him. When Cec was interviewed he gave a bit of his background. He said that he had enjoyed being a cadet at school so when they heard the first reports of the war he decided that he was going to be a soldier. In the publication he is quoted as saying: First came the war, then the rations. The rations we had were horrible. Everything was pretty bad those days. I would go as far to say that everybody was everybody’s friends in the war and if one of them died they’d just let it be, because really there was nothing they could do about it. He goes on to say: MAIN COMMITTEE The war was indescribable, it was just so hard to look at all the people who took pride in their country just fighting till death right in front of your eyes Young Tynan Jayne interviewed his grandfather who was a young boy during the war. He recalls: One chilly August morning in 1945, I was walking to school with my sisters, Carmen and Shirley, when suddenly the big air raid siren screamed to life. People stopped everywhere, unsure what to do, terrified, fearing an attack. I stood paralysed to the spot, searching the faces around me for clues on what to do. Moments later the local newsagent, Mr Cook, came racing out of his shop yelling. “The war is over, the war is over!” The Japanese had surrendered. There is another interview with Mrs June Bickle. I do not have the time to go into it as far as I would like to; I will just quote the first part. June is very well known and well loved throughout our community. The article says: Every ANZAC Day and every Remembrance Day the people will see June Bickle with two flower posies to lay in tribute; you will also find June at the Field of Remembrance planting two wooden crosses. One of June’s tributes is for her late husband, Alan Bickle, who was a long term president of both the RSL Memorial Club Ltd and also the president of the Toronto RSL Sub-Branch. The other tribute is for Charlie, who was killed in action in 1941. Charlie was June’s brother. The article goes on: ... at just eighteen years of age Ordinary Seaman Patrick was on his first ever voyage on a Naval ship. He was on the HMAS Sydney when he lost his life. As many people have said, this is not to honour war; this is to honour the sacrifice that our veterans made to ensure that we all live in a democracy and in a safe land as we do todayand that that continues on for our children as well. All the commemorations around Toronto that weekend had an empty chair sitting there with an Australian flag, a tin hat and a pair of boots. Peter Stephenson, who was the publicity officer on that organising committee and was also the secretary of the Toronto RSL subbranch, wrote a poem about this and these are Peter’s words. The poem is called An Empty Chair. A single chair sits empty: Our flag is draped about And on its seat sits still: A ‘‘tin-hat’’ and boots at its feet: We may see this empty chair And think of nothing else: Yet as we celebrate our Vict’ry Ghosts watch on and smile: This is not an empty chair For in it sits the spirit: Of those who’ve gone before us Those who’ve shown the way This chair is here to remind us: MAIN COMMITTEE Of those who could not Be with us in the flesh today: They’re here yet all the same So as we gaze upon this chair Let us see the faces Of young and vibrant warriors: Sitting with us, in this place Let’s take peace and joy Their work was not in vain: Let’s celebrate the past Knowing they are freed of pain I know Peter is very proud of that poem, and so he should be. The Prime Minister, while speaking to this motion in this House, paid tribute to Australia’s wartime Prime Minister, John Curtin. He said: ... to our own Prime Minister at the time, John Curtin, who died on 5 July 1945 and was thus denied the opportunity to see the victory to which his leadership had made a very significant contribution. I pay unconditional tribute to the contribution that he made in the time he was Prime Minister during World War II. In his recent biography of John Curtin, author David Day wrote: Curtin committed his life to achieving a better Australia for all its citizens ... He was of that optimistic generation that came to adulthood in the wake of Federation and which had its hopes tempered by the horrors of the First World War. Despite that experience and the years of the Great Depression, or perhaps because of them, Curtin continued to devote himself to improving the lives of ordinary Australians. It was his hope for a better Australia that drove him, at a terrible cost to his health, to galvanise Australians against the dangers of a military invasion that would have destroyed those hopes for all time. In conclusion, I once again honour all those veterans and widows of the Charlton electorate. I wish them all the best of good wishes and health. I pay tribute to all who made such an important and significant contribution to our history. We must never forget the tragedy of war, and future generations must commit to doing whatever is needed to ensure that the international community works towards world peace encompassing respect and justice for all global citizens. being born in June 1941, I want to talk about some memories. I was just over four when the war ended. I remember vividly my Uncle Bill, Bill Lostetter. He was an American Marine and he married my mum’s sister, my Aunt May, who was a teenage American war bride. I remember when Uncle Bill was on leave in Australia going around to my grandmother and Grandpa’s place in Hampton and seeing him there in his gear and being impressed. Uncle Bill served in Guadalcanal, one of the areas of huge loss for the American Marines, and Iwo Jima and all those sorts of areas. My Aunty May was shipped, with many other teenage American war brides, across the Pacific in very dangerous conditions with their young children. Aunt May arrived on the west coast of America and then was sent by train across to Cincinnati in Ohio to live with Uncle Bill’s family. She had never met them before. She did MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Quick (Franklin) (6.08 Pm)
theText: As I am the oldest member of the ALP in the House,not know whether she would ever see him again, but this was her new family in a strange country and she subsequently settled there. When Uncle Bill returned from the war they moved to Downey in California. I have other memories of that time. As I said, we lived in Hampton. We had an air-raid shelter in the backyard. I remember as a young four-year-old-the eldest in the familyclambering in and out of the air-raid shelter; it was a sort of cubbyhouse. I also remember the searchlights in the sky over Melbourne. A bit later, we moved up to Ballarat because my grandparents were ageing. I also remember the rationing and going to the grocer with mum with a ration book. I still have it at home, and it is one of my proud treasures. Those were the days of rationing and small amounts of butter, sugar and tea. That was before plastics were invented. There was no such thing as putting your recycling out. Everyone had chooks. We used to collect the horse manure, because the bread and milk were delivered by horse and cart, and we had a wonderful garden sprinkled liberally with horse manure. I remember my father telling me after the war had ended and I was getting towards the stage of going to school about the contributions made by some of his mates who had served with him in the First World War; they were young enough to participate in the Second World War and had gone back for a double dose. Fortunately, my dad was wounded seriously enough in the First World War not to have to venture a second try. I remember when a neighbour, Clarrie Everett, a 19-year-old, left for the Middle East and served in the African desert. He was withdrawn from there and was expected to-and did-fight in the Pacific. He went from the trauma of the heat, the dry and the dust of the African campaign to the heat, the wet, the damp and the unknown of the jungles of the Pacific. He was so tormented that, not long after he returned, he ended up killing himself. I remember the ANZAC Day marches in the forties and, as a child, proudly going along and watching my father march. Remember that, in the late forties, most of the guys from the First World War were still in their 40s-and there were the young blokes who had come back from the Second World War marching proudly. The ANZAC Day marches lasted forever and ever. SinceI have been a member of the federal parliament I have visited the Kokoda Trail, Lae, Wewak and Madang. I have visited parts of the Marshall Islands and have seen first hand some of the battlefields and war memorials. I was in Lae and Wewak when the rain absolutely pelted down. I thought, ‘How in the name of creation could you ever fight anybody in these conditions?’ It was 33 or 34 degrees, there were inches and inches of rain and it was real jungle. How could you fight and survive in something like that? I remember children who had Winston as part of their name. The Prime Minister’s middle name is Winston and so is my brother’s-John Winston Howard and Robert Winston Quick. I remember the saying about the Yanks being ‘overpaid, oversexed and over here’. I remember hearing stories about the ‘battle of Spencer Street’ when a train load of Americans came in saying, ‘Don’t worry fellas, we’ll look after your women for you!’ A few people got rather excited and discharged weapons, and some died as a result of that confrontation. I remember going out to where the American soldiers were based in the forests in Ballarat when I was a young cub and unexpectedly finding a pistol that had been left behind. I remember wondering whether I should stick it in my rucksack and go home, excited, but I must have been well trained, because I handed it over to my sixer and then it was handed over to the scoutmaster. As I got older, being a student of history, I tried to get in touch with many of the MAIN COMMITTEE diggers of the Second World War who had served in the Pacific, to try to understand some of the experiences and traumas they experienced. One of my best mates’ fathers, Bob Brownlie, who served in the Air Force, who was almost like a surrogate father to me, told me of his experiences in the Pacific. Most of us have organised a variety of events in our electorates to pay due respect and homage to these people-as people have said, not just to the men but to the women. As a student of history, I remember reading of the tragedy that beset the Australian nurses in the Pacific, who were captured by the Japanese and most of whom were executed. Vivian Bullwinkel is the famous nurse who survived to tell the story. Women stayed at home and worked in industry. Growing up in the Mallee, I knew of the role of women in the bush who stayed and worked to ensure that the farms continued, because in those days most of the men who could enrol did enrol. It is a time that we should not forget. Most of these people are now well into their 80s, and many are in their 90s. I think we have learnt the lesson from the First World War where, tragically, we let them get to the stage that the Second World War guys are at at the moment and suddenly realised that they were dying in vast numbers. There are now only three of them left. Someone mentioned Australia Remembers and Con Sciacca. I think what we are doing here with Victory in the Pacific goes some way to recognising the wonderful role that they played in ensuring that we live in the best country in the world, with the democracy that many people dream of. When I have my thanksgiving celebrations and hand out the medallions on 28 October, I will do it with a tear in my eye because, as I said, there are strong links through my family and through many of my friends’ parents who are no longer with us. I would like to pay tribute publicly to all of these people who have contributed much to our history. Ms BURKE (Chisholm) (6.18 pm)-I too want to make some remarks in respect of Victory in the Pacific Day. I want to start by thanking the government for going to the effort of recognising this day and providing sufficient funds for all our electorates to honour this celebration. It is quite interesting that, for years and years, our celebrations of the Australian war effort have concentrated on World War I, so it was fascinating, appropriate and timely to actually do something in respect of World War II. I hope, as members of parliament, all of us will continue this tradition-be it funded or not, whether there are medals or not-and do something on this day in years to come, because I think it reinforces for the generations who have no recollection or linkage to the war whatsoever that people did make a great sacrifice. In those traditional words, lest we forget. This also gives us a time to recall that we do honour those who gave their lives, but we also continue to have Australian service men and women serving for our country overseas. The notion of a returned service man or woman is not gone, and we still have people returning from conflicts, returning injured, but, touch wood, not returning dead. We need to recall that people continue to engage in active service on behalf of our country. I, like everyone else in this place, was privileged to be part of many ceremonies for VP Day. On the day itself we had two very moving services. One was at the Oakleigh RSL, where a phenomenal speech was given by Mal Carson, the past president of the Waverley RSL. Many people attended that fantastic service. I want to thank Neil Slaughter, at the Waverley RSL, for being the driving force behind that. I want to thank Chris and Peter, a phenomenal MAIN COMMITTEE duo, at the Oakleigh RSL, for all their efforts, and I also want to thank Ray Scott at the Clayton RSL for the work he did on that day. So in the morning we had that service. In the afternoon we coordinated through the Box Hill RSL, and a big thank you to Tony Bowden for that. We invited students from the local schools to attend a memorial service, and we asked grades 5 and 6 to be present. We provided them with a base to make their own wreaths, and they could do whatever theme they wanted. We also asked them to provide some poetry for the day. I would like to share with you some phenomenally inspirational words from children who have no direct experience of these conflicts. Kingswood College Junior School students wrote: To the men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in the Battle for the Pacific in WWII; We are grateful for giving us the freedom we enjoy today. We are now aware of the brutality and cruelty many of you suffered and the bravery and mateship you showed each other, which have become a symbol of the spirit of the Australian soldier. May history never forget you and may you continue to be honoured. St Benedict’s Primary School, my old alma mater: Some lived, Some died In our hearts, they survive. They fought for our freedom And some went to prison. We celebrate on August 15, When a new day had arisen. Mont Albert Primary School: As Sadako Sasaka was dying of leukemia in Hiroshima, she folded paper cranes as a prayer for health. On her deathbed she held one up and said, “I will write Peace on your wings and you will fly all over the world”. We share her dream of a world without war. It is up to the children of the world if Peace will come in the end. Give us the knowledge and wisdom to help prevent wars. We wish there were no war, violence or terrorism anywhere. We wish that everyone would co-operate, show tolerance and respect; and live in harmony. We wish that the cranes could fly free. Presbyterian Ladies’ College Junior School: On and on and he ran through the fields Each step he took would hopefully bring Australia one giant leap towards freedom. Japanese soldiers lay in wait on the muddy ground The sky was turning blood red as he ran towards the dreaded No Man’s Land. Bullets whistled past his ear Japanese gunmen laid low on the hills Waiting for the perfect moment to strike One moment felt like a lifetime Suddenly everything was silent A smooth, cold bullet punctured him MAIN COMMITTEE Slowly he fell to the ground “For Australia” he whispered silently in a hoarse voice When would the terror and bloodshed end? Hiroshima devastated along with the hopes of innocent civilians. A white flag rose and the war came to an end To this day we remember the brave who died for the greed of man. Our Lady’s Primary School: VP Day 60 years ago, PM Chifley announced, World War II was over. People started to dance. Over 1,000,000 Aussies fought to defend But for 40,000, their lives came to an end. Today we gather here to remember Those women and men whose lives changed forever. We celebrate the end of World War2 As world peace and freedom, we pursue. Mount Scopus Junior School: A day of mourning, a day of grief, Today we are going to lay this wreath. For the soldiers that have died, In their Australian pride. They dressed in green, With their fatal machine. Knowing their fate was near, They stood their ground, without any fear. In our minds the bravest men of Australia, The ones who fought for their country and gave up their lives. Clayton Primary School: To end a war that should not have started To bring joy to the broken-hearted. The men and women that went to war Swore to the enemies, that they would never fall. Many years have passed us by When many soldiers cried and died. We remember them on this day as VP day When World War2 went away. It’s been 60 long years Of pain and tears We’ve tried our best to comfort MAIN COMMITTEE The brave. We remember them today As heroes who set us all free, To live today in peace and harmony. Wattle Park Primary School: The war was bloody, The guns never stopped, And there was a good chance that you would be shot. Lots were killed, 40,000 in all, And then there was no fighting, The end of World War. Soldiers died, To keep us free, To save Australia For you and me. Kerrimuir Primary School quoted from Rudyard Kipling’s Ode, which he wrote for the commemoration of the Melbourne Shrine of Remembrance. I am going to read just a couple of stanzas: SO LONG as memory, valour, and faith endure, Let these stones witness, through the years to come, How once there was a people fenced secure Behind great waters girdling a far home. Their own and their land’s youth ran side by side Heedless and headlong as their unyoked seasLavish o’er all, and set in stubborn pride Of judgment, nurtured by accepted peace. Thus, suddenly, war took them-seas and skies Joined with the earth for slaughter. In a breath They, scoffing at all talk of sacrifice, Gave themselves without idle words to death. … … … Then they returned to their desired landThe kindly cities and plains where they were bredHaving revealed their nation in earth’s sight So long as sacrifice and honour stand, And their own sun at the hushed hour shall light The shrine of these their dead! MAIN COMMITTEE I found the whole ceremony incredibly moving. Some World War II veterans were present in the audience and there was not a dry eye in the house. We were also very blessed to have a veteran address the group. The children and I were quite stunned to find that this man had spent six years on the front line. He survived, he came back and 60 years later he was still alive. I, too, asked various people what they remembered about the end of the war. My mother said, ‘I was pretty young and I think we got a day off school.’ My dad said that his most vivid memory was a couple of weeks later when he was sitting around at home as usual. A whole bunch of people were sitting around having a cup of tea-I come from pretty good Irish stock-and someone said to dad, ‘Barney’-that is how they referred to him-‘see that bloke in the corner; he’s your dad,’ and it was the first time he had met him. He had returned from World War II. Dad was probably about eight. He had no recollections of him prior to going to war, and there was this man in the corner who was his father. He lived for only a couple more years. My father said that the most vivid memory he has of his childhood was meeting the man who was his father. My grandfather served in World WarI and World War II. Like many of us, we have connections to this horror. I hope that these celebrations and commemorations demonstrate to those people who fought for us so long ago that we do not forget. We thank them for their service, we commemorate them and, hopefully, as I said, we will not let this pass as a one-off. As electorates, we will share the valour of our World War II heroes and remember them. It was not just the men who fought; many Australian women fought and many Australian women did their bit back home. All of Australia was at war at that time. Sadly, I have two regrets about this occasion. I would like to put on the record my sadness for Norm Furness, from the 2nd 22nd Battalion, who was hoping to get back to Rabaul this year for a commemorative service. Veterans were sent there by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. Sadly, Norm’s group in Melbourne were not made aware of that commemoration and no-one from his regiment, who was on the front line, was given the chance to attend that ceremony. I am disappointed on their behalf. I am also disappointed on behalf of a couple of veterans in my area-particularly Cyril Ashton, who was a citizen of the United Kingdom at the time. He was conscripted aged 19. He did his war service. He did his bit at the hospital where they sewed up what they referred to as ‘the guinea pigs’-those people who came down during those tragic air battles over England. Sadly, as his service was not recognised as being part of a conflict because he was not actually overseas-although in Cyril’s words ‘They were dropping bombs on me every day, so I figured I was probably in a war zone-he was not entitled to a 60th anniversary medallion and that caused him some grief. I would like to thank all those people involved, particularly Ric from my office who did such great work to make our medal presentation the splendid day it was. To the Mount Scopus children who came and presented, on behalf of the Jewish community, their memories of war, my thanks. Thanks to the Pacific Island dancers who came and represented the Pacific Islands and all those who partook in the ceremony. Lest we forget. Debate adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 6.31 pm MAIN COMMITTEE Medicare (Question No. 966) Can he say when a Medicare Office will be opened in Gungahlin in the electoral division of Fraser, one of eight new offices to be opened, as indicated in the Health Insurance Commission’s announcement of 31 August 2004 which can be viewed on its website. Medicare Australia has leased premises for a new Medicare office in Gungahlin, ACT. The site chosen is in a newly developed shopping centre called ‘The G’ which is owned and developed by Coles. The Gungahlin Medicare Office opened on 19 September 2005. Centrelink: Debt Recovery (Question No. 968) Mr Bowen asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005: (1) Are debt collection companies engaged to assist in the recovery of Family Debt overpayments; if so, what sum was paid to debt collection companies during 2004? (2) How many overpayments were referred to debt collection companies? (3) What is the name of each debt collection company engaged for this purpose? Yes, debt collection companies are engaged by Centrelink to recover overpayments from non-current customers for a range of payment types, including Family Tax Benefit. Debt collection arrangements vary from year to year. Massage Service (Question No. 992) Mr Bowen asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 10 May 2005: (1) Does any agency for which the Minister is responsible pay for massages for its staff; if so, what sum did each agency spend on this purpose in 2004. (2) What was the cost per massage. (3) How many staff made use of this service. The Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) (1) DEST does not generally provide massages for staff on an ongoing basis. On occasions, massages are arranged on-site, but paid for by participating staff. In one isolated case, DEST paid a total of $550 (excluding GST) for massages for staff in the Melbourne Office. This was a local area OH&S arrangement in response to staff continuing to work while the floor was being refurbished around them. (2) The massages cost $12.50 (excluding GST). (3) 44 staff made use of the service.
title: Victory In The Pacific

speaker: Mr Mcmullan Asked The Minister For Human Services, In Writing, On 10 May 2005:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Questacon operates as a separate business unit with its own Certified Agreement, under which Questacon paid a total of $1,850 (excluding GST) for massages for staff under a Health Awareness Program. (2) The massages cost $12.50 each (excluding GST), in addition to a fee of $100 (excluding GST) to hire the massage chair for 5 days. (3) 140 staff made use of the service. None of the Agencies under the Portfolio have provided massages for their staff. Medicare (Question No. 1123) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005: Are there any plans to close the Medicare office located in 16 Walkers Arcade, Coburg. Medicare Australia has no plans to close the Coburg Medicare Office located at 16 Walkers Arcade, Coburg, Victoria. Medicare (Question No. 1144) Mr Price asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005: (1) What year was the Medicare office at Mt Druitt closed? (2) How many transactions were completed in the last 12 months of operation at the Mt Druitt Medicare Office? (3) What was the value of dead rent paid for the Mt Druitt Office? (4) In respect of each Medicare office that has been opened since the Medicare Office at Mt Druitt was closed, (a) what is its address, (b) in which electoral division is it located, and (c) what is the annual number of transactions it processes? (5) For the most recent calendar year for which the information is available, which Medicare office processed the (a) highest and (b) lowest number of transactions and how many did it process? (6) For the most recent calendar year for which the information is available, what is the (a) average and (b) modal number of transactions processed by all Medicare offices combined? (1) 1998. (2) 63,453 transactions were processed from April 1997 to end March 1998. (3) $54,899.48. (4) The following information relates to those Medicare offices opened since the Mt Druitt Medicare Office was closed: Medicare Opened (a) Address (b) Electorate (c) No. of Transactions Office Rosebud 24/6/04 Shop 15, Rosebud VilFlinders 124,363 lage Shopping Centre, (1/7/04 – 30/6/05) 967 Point Nepean Road, Rosebud, VIC

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hockey

(2) How many media and communications officers were employed in the Minister’s department in 1996. (3) What sum was allocated to the media and communications unit in (a) 1996-1997, (b) 2004-2005, and (c) 2005-2006. (1) There are 14 media and communications employees currently employed in the Minister’s department. (2) This information is unavailable as the current Human Resources (HR) system is unable to access data prior to 1998. (3) A specific allocation is not made for media and communications other than for employee costs.
