Skilled Migration Programs (Question No. 1914) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 August 2005: (1) In respect of the placement of twelve departmental officers with employer industry organisations to assist employers to access Skilled Migration programs, (a) what process was used to select the employer organisations, (b) which employer organisations are involved, and (c) where will the officers be located. (2) What are the arrangements with the employer organisations concerning the operational costs of locating the officers with employer organisations and to whom will the officers be accountable for their day to day work. (3) In respect of the placement of department officers through the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) network, is the department aware that New Apprenticeship Centre staff located in the ACCI have been required in the past to assist in recruiting members to ACCI, if so, what action has been taken to ensure that such misuse of government resources for private commercial purposes does not occur.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Mr John Cobb-The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) Advertisements seeking expressions of interest were placed in The Australian, The Sydney Morning Herald, The Canberra Times and the Age on 21 May 2005. Industry Groups were asked to submit a brief proposal outlining how the department officers would be utilised and addressing the following selection criteria: extent of skills shortage, extent of education required in the industry, extent of organisation support available for the officer, and the work plan proposal. (b) The following industry groups are involved: Australian Chamber of Commerce& Industry Master Builders Association Housing Industry Association Motor Trades Association of Australia Australasian Railways Association Commerce Queensland Growcom National Farmers Federation Victorian Employer’s Chamber of Commerce& Industry Manufacturing & Engineering Skills Advisory Board Victoria Australian Industry Group Australian Business Ltd Association of Consulting Engineers Australia Australian Mines& Metals Association WA Resources Sector Consortium (CME & APPEA) Chamber of Commerce& Industry WA Business SA Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce& Industry Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce& Industry Restaurants & Catering Australia In addition, the department is also working closely with the Minerals Council of Australia but not on an outplaced basis. (c) The officers will be located in Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne, Darwin, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Brisbane. Some will have national and others state wide coverage. (2) The Department is responsible for salary, travel, equipment for presentations and related administrative costs. The host employer organisation will provide a work area, some equipment and administrative support needed for the day-to-day work of the officer. The officers remain accountable to the department. (3) DIMIA has taken steps to ensure clarity on the role and activities of the industry officers. A draft Deed of Agreement has been developed for signing with each host Industry group. The Deed identifies clearly the role of the industry officers and does not include membership recruitment activities. In addition, the Industry officers are developing business plans, in conjunction with the host industry group and the department. These plans will clearly outline the roles and responsibilities of the outposted officers. These will include advising on immigration options to the employer members of the organisation, promoting electronic lodgement and liaising on policy/procedural issues that require attention. The effectiveness of the program is being monitored through strategies such as monthly reports received from each industry officer on their activities and progress with the business plan. The program will be formally evaluated after nine months. Baxter Detention Centre (Question No. 1927) Mr Georganas asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 August 2005: Do security staff at Baxter detention centre dispense prescribed medication to detainees; if so, has the wrong medication ever been dispensed to a detainee by security staff. Mr John Cobb-The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Where medication is required by detainees at Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF) at night or on Sundays, Detention Services Officers deliver medications prescribed to detainees by authorised medical staff by way of “Webster Packs”. A “Webster Pack” is an A4 card, printed with the patient’s name, medication and daily/weekly dosage. Attached to the front of the card is a clear plastic blister pack which a pharmacist fills with the appropriate medication, thus enabling the delivery of medication by non-clinical staff. Pharmacists are the only people able to fill a Webster Pack and this is done in accordance with prescriptions authorised by a qualified medical practitioner. Delivery of medication via Webster Packs is undertaken in accordance with procedures that have been approved by independent medical experts. Where officers deliver medication via Webster Packs the Webster Packs are returned to the Health Centre as part of the control process where nurses review the medication delivered and note the detainee’s medical chart accordingly. Webster Packs were introduced at Baxter IDF due to intimidating behaviour by detainees towards nursing staff who previously dispensed after hours medication from trolleys at the accommodation units. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs’ (DIMIA) records indicate that on 1 December 2004 a detainee advised that he had been provided with medication of a type that he no longer required on 29 November 2004. The Detention Services Provider (DSP) was asked to investigate the matter. DIMIA was advised that the detainee had left the IDF and that no medication was provided to the detainee on the date in question. Neither DIMIA nor the DSP is aware of any other incidents involving incorrect medication other than that described above, which has not been substantiated. Foreign Nationals (Question No. 1932) Ms Roxon asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 9 August 2005: (1) What were the grounds for the decision to waive the jurisdiction of the Queensland courts to try Lance Corporal Craig Meeks and Staff Sergeant Beryl Wilson Jr in relation to the alleged assault and attempted murder of Mr Heath Twomey of Townsville. (2) Can he explain the process that was followed in making this decision, including details on the date of the decision, the name and position of the decision-maker and the information collected before the decision was made. (3) At the time that this decision was made, what assurances or undertakings did the Government receive from the Government of the United States of America as to the steps that would be taken to ensure that Lance Corporal Meeks and Staff Sergeant Wilson would face charges for the alleged assault and attempted murder of Mr Twomey. (4) Did the Government request that the US military proceedings in this matter take place in Townsville or elsewhere in Australia; if so, on what grounds was this request denied. (5) What steps did the Government take to ensure that Mr Twomey or other Townsville-based witnesses could give evidence in the US military proceedings. (6) What steps did the Government take to monitor the conduct of this matter through the US military justice system. (7) What steps, if any, did the Government take to assist the US authorities that investigated and tried this matter, including assistance to prosecutors. (8) When did the Government first become aware that no charges had been laid against Lance Corporal Meeks and that Staff Sergeant Wilson had been acquitted. (9) What steps did the Government take to ensure that Mr Twomey and his family were informed of developments in the matter, including the acquittal and the decision not to lay charges. (10) Why has he failed to acknowledge or reply to correspondence (dated 5 March 2005 and 24 May 2005) on this matter from Mr Michael Reynolds, Member for Townsville in the Queensland Parliament. (11) Since 1996, how many times has the Government waived the jurisdiction of an Australian, State or Territory court to try foreign nationals accused of crimes committed in Australia so that the foreign nationals could be tried in another country. (12) In respect of each occasion since 1996 that the Government has waived the jurisdiction of an Australian, State or Territory court, (a) what were the details of the case including the alleged crime, (b) what were the grounds for the waiver, (c) which other country was involved, and (d) what was the outcome of trial in that country. (1) The decision-maker considered a broad range of factors such as the views and wishes of the complainant, the need to deter recurrence of the alleged conduct by visiting forces, the length of the trial processes in each jurisdiction, the comparative penalties in each jurisdiction and the comparative costs of trial in each jurisdiction. (2) The decision was made on 19 May 2004, by Robert Cornall, Secretary of the Attorney-General’s Department. The following information was collected before the decision was made: the views of Mr Heath Twomey, the views of the Queensland Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the difference in penalties, the comparative costs in either case and who would bear them, and the difference in compensation arrangements. (3) The decision to waive Australia’s jurisdiction in this case was made on the basis that the marines would be appropriately tried under US military laws, which comprise disciplinary as well as criminal sanctions. (4) No. (5) Once transferred, the United States has jurisdiction and it is not appropriate for Australia to interfere in the United States’ proceedings.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(6) Once jurisdiction was transferred, the United States had the responsibility to update Mr Twomey about the proceedings. Since finding out about the outcome in this case, the Government sought further information from the US about the handling of this matter. It is regrettable that the US did not inform the complainant about the outcome of this matter. However, the Government has since been advised that the US has spoken and written to the complainant about the approach to the trial and its outcome. (7) The matter was thoroughly investigated by the US military, with the cooperation of the Queensland Police. (8) The Department contacted the US Embassy on 21 April 2005, to enquire about the Meeks and Wilson case and was informed of the outcome. (9) Since finding out about the outcome in this case, the Government sought further information from the US about the handling of this matter. It is regrettable that the US did not inform the complainant about the outcome of this matter. However, the Government has since been advised that the US has spoken and written to the complainant about the approach to the trial and its outcome. (10) I replied to both of these letters on 7 July 2005. (11) Since 1996, the Government has waived jurisdiction under section 10 of the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963 over four individuals. (12) Request1 (a) Charged with rape and sexual intercourse without consent, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, and (d) 18 years confinement, reduced to lowest military grade and dishonourable discharge. Request2 (a) Charged with being an accessory to rape, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, (d) 2 years confinement, reduced to lowest military grade, ‘total forfeiture’ (ie no pay), and dishonourable discharge. Request3 (a) Charged with aggravated assault, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, (d) investigated by US and charges not progressed. Request4 (a) Charged with attempted murder, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, and (d) acquitted. Classified Material (Question No. 1956) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 9 August 2005: (1) In respect of the provisions of the Commonwealth Protective Security Survey Manual regarding checks on Top Secret files, what audit procedures have been undertaken by his department to identify problems in the management, security and location or retention of classified material held by Commonwealth agencies from 1998 to the present (2) Have any of the audits identified discrepancies in the management, security and location or retention of classified material held by Commonwealth agencies. (3) In respect of the correspondence between Deputy Secretary, Mr Miles Jordana, and the Herald Sun reporter, Mr Mark Dunn, dated 29 June 2005 which confirmed that the Attorney-General’s Department holds material “coming into the ambit” of an FOI request lodged by Mr Dunn and that the material identifies a number of ‘discrepancies’ of the type mentioned in his request, how many discrepancies have been identified. (4) What is the nature of the discrepancies and do any of the discrepancies constitute security breaches. (5) Were any of the discrepancies identified in relation to classified documents; if so, how many classified documents were involved and at what security level were these documents classified. (6) What specific steps have been taken by the department since the first security discrepancies were identified to prevent further breaches or discrepancies from occurring. (7) Can he confirm that the view of his department as expressed in the decision not to release information relating to security discrepancies that “vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the storing and retention of such material are likely to exist within the Department” is correct. (1) Responsibility for the management of classified material rests with each agency’s Chief Executive Officer/Secretary. Each Department is responsible for auditing their own security procedures. Australian Government agencies complete an annual survey on their protective security compliance and the results are considered by Government. The Attorney-General’s Department Security Unit is responsible for security audits internally. (2) The Department does not conduct protective security audits of other Australian Government agencies. The internal audits conducted by the Department’s Security Unit noted minor discrepancies in the management, security and location of the Department’s information holdings. (3) The information recorded is largely qualitative in nature and cannot be readily converted to numbers or statistics. (4) The discrepancies noted in the internal audits related to procedural errors in the management of Departmental information holdings. These were minor. Identifying and monitoring these procedural errors assisted the Department to improve its security practices. (5) These discrepancies related to classified and unclassified documents and files at varying classifications. All breaches were minor and so no investigations were undertaken. The exact number of documents was not recorded in the audit reports, as the reports commonly focused on the procedural weaknesses in the affected areas. (6) The Department has conducted and continues to conduct security audits and make recommendations for improving security practice. The results of these audits are monitored and targeted security training is provided where necessary. The Department also has in place a security awareness training program for all staff. (7) The answer is no. The response provided to Mr Dunn was that: “The material sought by you identifies the type of vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the storing and retention of such material that are unavoidably likely to exist within the Department from time to time.” The discrepancies identified within the Department have been of a minor nature and therefore were not investigated. The Department undertakes security awareness training and continues to monitor security procedures to ensure compliance with the standards detailed in the Protective Security Manual. New Apprenticeships Employer Incentive Scheme (Question No. 1978) Ms Macklin asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 9 August 2005: (1) What are the fifty qualifications for which the highest number of incentive payments were made under the New Apprenticeship Employer Incentive Scheme for (a) 2001, (b) 2002, (c) 2003, and (d) 2004.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) For each of the qualifications listed in part (1), what was the total value of the payments for (a) 2001, (b) 2002, (c) 2003, and (d) 2004. The following four tables list the fifty New Apprenticeships qualifications against which the highest number of New Apprenticeships employer incentives payments have been made, as well as total amount of incentives paid against each of those qualifications for the calendar years 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004. The totalled payments cover the full range of the New Apprenticeships Incentives Programme, including commencement, progression and completion payments as well as special and additional incentives. It is important to note that there is no direct correlation between the number and value of claims as this information reflects only those claims submitted by employers. You should also note that traditional trades qualifications are under-represented in these tables because until recently most traditional trade apprenticeships were conducted using different qualification codes for each State and Territory. Most apprenticeships are now covered by single National Training Package qualifications and this is reflected in the higher position in the 2004 table for occupations such as electricians, carpenters and hairdressers. Baxter Detention Centre (Question No. 2102) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 17 August 2005: (1) What enquiries did the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, as the Acting Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, make before issuing the statement on 26 April that “All people working as psychologists at immigration detention facilities are appropriately trained and registered with relevant agencies” in response to credible information that unregistered psychologists were practising at the Baxter Detention Centre in contravention of South Australian law and in clear breach of the Detention Services Contract between DIMIA and GSL. (2) Is the Minister aware that the South Australian Psychological Board pursued the matter and found that the psychologists were not registered and consequently advised them that any further breaches of the law would be referred to the Crown Solicitor’s office for prosecution. (3) Can the Minister account for, or explain, the Acting Minister’s apparent error in this matter. (4) What action has the Minister taken to improve the process by which statements are issued from (a) the Minister’s and (b) the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs’ office since becoming aware that the statement issued on 26 April 2005 was incorrect. (5) In respect of the breach of clause 7.1.9 of the Detention Services Contract between DIMIA and GSL which requires that “All detainees must be able to access timely and effective primary health care, including psychological and psychiatric services. At all times, care needs must be identified and delivered by qualified, registered and appropriately trained health care professionals” can the Minister provide the date on which GSL informed DIMIA of the Default that occurred, as it is required to do under clause 8.1.1 of the Detention Services Contract. (6) Can the Minister advise whether DIMIA has issued a Default Notice under clause 8.1.2(a) in relation to this matter. Mr John Cobb-The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) to (4) The intent of the statement of 26 April 2005 referred to the training and registration of psychologists employed on an ongoing basis, all of whom were registered with the appropriate professional board in a state of Australia. After investigation by my Department, this remains the case. However, after further investigation, it is true that two psychologists who provided short-term relief services at Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF) had omitted to obtain mutual recognition of registration in South Australia in advance of this. They obtained the proper registration on 2 May and 4 May 2005 respectively and both apologised in writing to the South Australian Psychological Board for their oversight. The Acting Minister’s statement was not intended to mislead. It was interpreted in a way that was not anticipated at the time. The relevant officer has apologised to me for not being clearer in preparing the statement. After requests for more detailed information, on 7 July 2005 the Detention Services Provider (GSL Australia) advised my Department of a total of fifteen instances in which visiting psychologists providing services at the Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre and Baxter IDF had failed to comply with state mutual recognition registration requirements while providing short-term relief or visiting services. In all cases, there is no indication that the psychologist involved did not have the appropriate skills and training to provide psychological services. All psychologists were trained and properly registered to work as psychologists in the state in which they usually worked. (5) to (6) My Department does not consider that clause 7.1.9 of schedule 2 of the Detention Services Contract was breached in these instances as the health care professionals were in fact registered as psychologists in other states and there is no suggestion that they were not appropriately qualified and trained to provide psychological services to detainees. However, my Department does consider that there were breaches of Immigration Detention Standard 7.1.3, which requires staff to be registered in the state or territory where they are working. My Department has made it clear to GSL that these breaches are totally unacceptable. Significant sanctions were imposed on GSL as a result of the breaches. New Apprenticeship Centres (Question No. 2114) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 18 August 2005: (1) For each financial year since the Government opened New Apprenticeship Centres (NACs), (a) what sum has the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) been allocated to operate NACs, and (b) in which locations has the ACCI operated NACs. (2) For each financial year since the Government opened New Apprenticeship Centres (NACs) and for each NAC, how many (a) new apprenticeships and (b) traditional trade apprenticeships have been (i) commenced and (ii) completed. (3) For each financial year since the Government opened New Apprenticeship Centres (NACs), in which skill area and with which employers have ACCI operated NACs achieved new apprenticeships and traditional trade apprenticeships to completion.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Hardgrave

The definition of apprentices uses a TYIMS identifier which classifies individual qualifications into an apprenticeship or traineeship according to how the qualification is assessed in a majority of States/ Territories. The financial year shown relates to the date of commencement of the New Apprenticeship. (ii) (a) and (b) The following table shows traditional trade apprenticeships and total New Apprenticeships completions recorded against each New Apprenticeships Centre since 1 May 1998. Note that completion data on TYIMS is not comprehensive as employers are only obliged to report successful completions to their New Apprenticeships Centre where they wish to claim a completion incentive. The definition of apprentices uses a TYIMS identifier which classifies individual qualifications into an apprenticeship or traineeship according to how the qualification is assessed in a majority of States/ Territories. This definition may differ from that used by other organisations. In responding to this question traditional trade apprenticeships have been identified as ‘Apprentices’ in the tables. The financial year shown relates to the date of completion of the New Apprenticeship. As a result data will increase over time as more completions are recorded on TYIMS with completion dates in those financial years. All data is drawn TYIMS as at 19 August 2005. fication The following table shows traditional trade apprenticeships completions since 1 May 1998 recorded against New Apprenticeships Centres affiliated with the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry by the Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) industry of the employer. Individual employer names could not be provided in response to this question as this would generate over 50,000 rows of data. Note that completion data on TYIMS is not comprehensive as employers are only obliged to report successful completions to their New Apprenticeships Centre where they wish to claim a completion incentive. The definition of apprentices uses a TYIMS identifier which classifies individual qualifications into an apprenticeship or traineeship according to how the qualification is assessed in a majority of States/ Territories. This definition may differ from that used by other organisations. The financial year shown relates to the date of completion of the New Apprenticeship. As a result data will increase over time as more completions are recorded on TYIMS with completion dates in those financial years. All data is drawn TYIMS as at 26 August 2005. Schools (Question No. 2146) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 18 August 2005: What sum under the Flagpole Funding Initiative was granted to each (a) government and (b) nongovernment school in the postcode area (i) 3337, (ii) 3338, (iii) 3435, (iv) 3437, (v) 3438, (vi) 3440, (vii) 3441, and (viii) 3442. (a) Government Schools (i) In postcode area 3337 one government school (Melton Primary School) received $1,198.64 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (ii) In postcode area 3338 no funding was provided to government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (iii) In postcode area 3435 one government school (Lancefield Primary School) received $1,345.00 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (iv) (v), (vi), (vii) In postcode areas 3437, 3438, 3440 and 3441 no funding was provided to government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (viii) In postcode area 3442 one government school (Woodend Primary School) received $1,377 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (b) Non-government Schools (i) In postcode area 3337 one non-government school (St Dominic’s Primary School) received $1,185.50 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. (ii) (iii), (iv), (v), (vi), (vii) and (viii) In postcode areas 3338, 3435, 3437, 3438, 3440, 3441 and 3442 no funding was provided to non-government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative. Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (Question No. 2237) Ms Hoare asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 5 September 2005: (1) Can the Minister confirm that the Government is seeking ways to encourage migrants and refugees to settle in regional areas. (2) What is the Government doing so that in encouraging the regional settlement of migrants and refugees care is taken to ensure that resettlement is consolidated and that value is placed on the knowledge, networks and industry insight of the ‘local connection’. (3) Is the Minister aware that the tender to provide the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS) in the Newcastle and Hunter Region has been conferred on a consortium led by the Australian Centre for Languages (ACL) which is a Sydney-based, for profit, company with no local history or reputation in the Newcastle and Hunter region. (4) Is the Minister aware that with only a month before the new contracts for IHSS delivery commence, ACL has (a) shown no evidence of its client focus or seamless service delivery in the critical weeks of the roll-out, (b) paid one half-hour visit to the area, and (c) made one phone call to Centrelink in the region.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(5) Is the Minister concerned that ACL has shown a lack of commitment to the regional settlement of migrants and refugees and has ignored local knowledge, insight and expertise; if not, can the Minister explain the basis on which the Government is satisfied with ACL’s commitment to the settlement of migrants and refugees in the Newcastle and Hunter Region. (6) Will the Minister ensure that local expertise will be included in the current and future tenders for IHSS service delivery; if not, why not. Mr John Cobb-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes, in line with the recommendations of the 2003 Report of the Review of Settlement Services for Migrants and Humanitarian Entrants and the Government’s broader strategy to increase regional migration, the Australian Government is actively encouraging new arrivals to settle in regional Australia. (2) The Australian Government is aware of the need to ensure that the appropriate settlement services are in place to cater for the particular needs of humanitarian entrants, family stream migrants and family members of skilled migrants with low English proficiency. In addition to available mainstream services, the Government delivers targeted assistance through the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS), the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) and the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS). (3) Yes, the contract to provide IHSS services in the Northern Metropolitan Region in NSW, encompassing the Newcastle and Hunter Region, has been awarded to a consortium led by the Australian Centre for Languages (ACL) and including Resolve FM, Mission Australia and STARTTS as partners. (4) There is significant evidence of the ACL consortium’s strong client focus and commitment to service delivery in the Newcastle and Hunter Region. Both Mission Australia and STARTTS have offices in Newcastle and ACL is acquiring an office in Newcastle. ACL is implementing a transition plan which was agreed by my Department and which includes a number of actions to facilitate a smooth transition to service delivery under the new arrangements. (5) Given that IHSS service delivery under new contracts does not begin until 1 October there is no evidence to suggest that the ACL consortium is not committed to the settlement of migrants and refugees in the Newcastle and Hunter Region. On the contrary, implementation activity already undertaken indicates that the consortium has a strong commitment to both regional settlement and to the utilisation of local knowledge. (6) Local knowledge and expertise was a requirement of the current IHSS tender and will be in any future IHSS tender. Sudanese Refugees (Question No. 2245) Mr Price asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 6 September 2005: (1) For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many Sudanese refugees have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division. (2) For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many other refugees from the African continent have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division. (3) For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many migrants from the African continent have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division. Mr John Cobb-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The information requested is not available by federal electorate without a very considerable investment of resources. The following information shows the State or Territory of settlement of refugee and other migrant entrants at 31 August 2005, by country of birth. For the purposes of this question, refugees have been defined as persons processed within visa subclasses 200 217 (Refugee& Humanitarian overseas sub-classes) and visa sub-class 866 (onshore Permanent Protection). The data does not include Temporary Protection Visa holders. (1) Sudanese refugees by State/Territory of settlement. Job Network Providers (Question No. 2275) Ms Bird asked the Minister for Workforce Participation, in writing, on 6 September 2005: (1) Is he aware that Job Network providers are requesting that job seekers with a disability, such as epilepsy, should not advise a potential employer of their disability in job interviews? (2) What are the guidelines for Job Network providers on advising job seekers of their obligation to disclose disabilities to potential employers. (1) No. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations has not directed Job Network members to request job seekers with a disability not to advise potential employers. (2) Job Network members are bound by the Employment Services Contract 2003-2006 to comply with all relevant Australian laws, including anti-discrimination laws, in their dealings with job seekers. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations maintains a dedicated web site, JobAble, to provide a wide range of information and strategies to assist Job Network members in servicing people with disabilities as well as information for employers. JobAble provides links to the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, including that recruitment questions about an applicant’s disability should be linked to the requirements of the vacancy.
